{{use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox cycling race report |name = 2015 Eschborn-Frankfurt City Loop |series = [[2015 UCI Europe Tour]] |date = 1 May 2015 |distance = 205 |unit = km |stages = 1 |previous = [[2014 Eschborn-Frankfurt City Loop|2014]] }} The '''2015 Eschborn-Frankfurt City Loop''' (in German '''Rund um den Finanzplatz Eschborn-Frankfurt''') was scheduled to be the 54th edition of the [[Eschborn-Frankfurt City Loop]] semi-classic cycling race; it would have taken place on 1 May 2015. The race was cancelled the day before it was scheduled to take place because of a suspected terrorist plot similar to the [[Boston Marathon bombing]].
== Planned event == The race was to have taken place on 1 May 2015 and was rated as a [[1.HC]] event by the [[Union Cycliste Internationale]] (UCI).<ref>{{cite web|title=Rund um den Finanzplatz Eschborn-Frankfurt 2015 – Classic|url=http://procyclingstats.com/race.php?id=150288|website=ProCyclingStats|accessdate=22 April 2015}}</ref> The planned route was {{convert|205|km}} in length, starting in [[Eschborn]] and ending in [[Frankfurt]]; the course included several hills.<ref>{{cite web|title=Strecke Elite HC – Guide|url=http://www.eschborn-frankfurt.de/_static/media/PDFs/Strecke-Elite-HC_2Seiten.pdf|website=eschborn-frankfurt.de|accessdate=22 April 2015|language=German|format=PDF}}</ref> The defending champion was [[Alexander Kristoff]] ({{ct|KAT|2015}}).<ref>{{cite web|title=Rund um den Finanzplatz Eschborn-Frankfurt 2014 – Classic|url=http://www.procyclingstats.com/race/Rund_um_den_Finanzplatz_Eschborn_Frankfurt_2014|website=ProCyclingStats|accessdate=22 April 2015}}</ref> The favourites for victory included Kristoff and [[John Degenkolb]] ({{ct|GIA|2015}}), who had between them won the [[2015 Milan–San Remo|Milan–San Remo]], the [[2015 Tour of Flanders|Tour of Flanders]] and the [[2015 Paris–Roubaix|Paris–Roubaix]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bijlsma|first1=Matthijs|title=Voorbeschouwing: Rund um den Finanzplatz Eschborn-Frankfurt 2015|url=http://www.wielerflits.nl/nieuws/63276/voorbeschouwing-rund-um-den-finanzplatz-eschborn-frankfurt-2015.html|accessdate=30 April 2015|work=Wielerflits|date=30 April 2015|language=Dutch}}</ref>
=== Teams === 22 teams were invited to take part in the race. Six of these were [[UCI WorldTeam]]s; seven were [[UCI Professional Continental]] teams; eight were German [[UCI Continental]] teams; the last was a German national team.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=Rund um den Finanzplatz Eschborn-Frankfurt|url=http://www.procyclingstats.com/race.php?id=150288&c=3|website=ProCyclingStats|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>
{{cyclingteamlist|title=UCI WorldTeams|KAT|ALM|GIA|LTS|SKY|IAM|year=2015}} {{cyclingteamlist|title=UCI Professional Continental teams|ROO|TNE|WGG|team1={{ct|AND|2015a}}|CUL|NRI|CCC|year=2015}} {{cyclingteamlist|title=UCI Continental teams|LKT|SSG|BAI|team1=[[Team Kuota-Lotto]]|RNR|SGT|team2=[[Team Heizomat]]|team3=[[MLP Team Bergstrasse]]|year=2015}} {{cyclingteamlist|title=National teams|team1=Germany|year=2015}}
== Suspected terrorist plot and cancellation == On 30 April 2015, the day before the race was due to have taken place, local authorities announced that it had been cancelled due to "indications of a possible threat to the population".<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/apr/30/german-cycling-race-cancelled-bomb-making-kit|title = German cycling race cancelled after discovery of bomb-making kit|last = |first = |date = 30 April 2015|work = [[The Guardian]]|access-date = 30 April 2015|via = |agency = Associated Press}}</ref> A couple, one of whom was described as a "suspected Islamic extremist", were arrested the previous day at their home in [[Oberursel (Taunus)|Oberursel]], which is along the race route.<ref name=":1" /> The couple arrested were identified as Halil D., 35, a German citizen of [[Turkey|Turkish]] origin, and Senay D., 34, thought to be a Turkish citizen.<ref name="Telegraph">{{Cite news|title=Frankfurt bike race cancelled over Islamist terror plot arrests |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/11577649/Frankfurt-bike-race-cancelled-over-Islamist-terror-plot-arrests.html|work=The Telegraph|date=1 May 2015}}</ref>
Various items were found in their house, including a homemade [[pipe bomb]], bomb-making materials, an [[automatic rifle]], bazooka ammunition and a canister full of petrol.<ref name="Telegraph"/><ref name="Reuters">{{Cite news|title=German police foil Islamist attack ahead of Frankfurt cycle race|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-security-idUSKBN0NL0YE20150430|agency=Reuters|date=30 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="CNN">{{Cite news|title=German police thwart Boston-style plot to bomb cycle race, source says|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/04/30/europe/germany-terror-arrests/|work=CNN|date=1 May 2015}}</ref> One of the couple had apparently bought [[hydrogen peroxide]] and alcohol at a hardware shop and had been seen exploring a forest along the race route.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://velonews.competitor.com/2015/04/news/in-the-news-police-foil-terror-threat-to-german-bike-race_368498|title = In the News: Police foil terror threat to German bike race|last = |first = |date = 30 April 2015|work = [[VeloNews]]|access-date = 30 April 2015|via = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.cyclingnews.com/news/rund-um-finanzplatz-eschborn-frankfurt-cancelled-after-police-thwart-possible-terrorist-action|title = Rund um Finanzplatz Eschborn-Frankfurt cancelled after police thwart possible terrorist action|last = |first = |date = 30 April 2015|work = [[Cyclingnews.com]]|access-date = 30 April 2015|via = }}</ref> He had connections to [[Salafist]]s in Frankfurt, including the group [[Dawa FFM]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nos.nl/artikel/2033278-terreuraanslag-in-duitsland-verijdeld.html|title = Duitse wielerwedstrijd afgelast wegens terreurdreiging|last = |first = |date = 30 April 2015|work = [[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting|NOS.nl]]|access-date = 30 April 2015|via = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Kontakt mit „Dawa FFM“ Mutmaßlicher Radrennen-Attentäter in salafistischer Szene vernetzt|url=http://www.berliner-zeitung.de/politik/kontakt-mit--dawa-ffm--mutmasslicher-radrennen-attentaeter-in-salafistischer-szene-vernetzt-23562240|work=Berliner Zeitung|date=25 January 2016|language=German}}</ref> The German newspaper ''[[Die Welt]]'' suggested that he was involved with [[Al-Qaida]], specifically [[Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]] (AQIM).<ref name="Telegraph"/><ref name="Reuters"/> According to German police the couple had also travelled to [[Spain]] to meet with members of [[Sharia4Spain]].<ref name="CNN"/> It has also been suggested that there may have been connections to Adem Yilmaz, one of those convicted as part of a [[2007 bomb plot in Germany|bomb plot in 2007]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Eckardt|first1=Andy|title=Frankfurt Prosecutor: Couple Arrested on Suspicion of Plotting 'Criminal Act'|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/turkish-couple-arrested-germany-suspicion-plotting-criminal-act-n351036|accessdate=30 April 2015|work=[[NBC News]]|date=30 April 2015}}</ref>
Security officials suggested that the couple may have been planning an attack similar to the [[2013 Boston Marathon bombing]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Halil D. was sentenced to two and a half years in prison in July 2016 for possession of illegal weapons and falsification of documents.<ref>{{Cite news|title=German bombmaker sentenced over illegal arms|url=http://www.dw.com/en/german-bombmaker-sentenced-over-illegal-arms/a-19376179|work=Deutsche Welle|date=4 July 2016}}</ref>

The '''71st World Science Fiction Convention''' ([[Worldcon]]), also known as '''LoneStarCon 3''', was held in [[San Antonio, Texas]], on August 29-September 2, 2013, at the [[Henry B. Gonzalez Convention Center]] and [[Marriott Rivercenter]].<ref name="sfwa110823"/><ref name="mom130802"/> The convention committee was chaired by Randall Shepherd. The convention was organized by Alamo Literary Arts Maintenance Organization, Inc. (ALAMO) which had previously organized [[LoneStarCon 2]], the 55th [[World Science Fiction Convention]], held in San Antonio in 1997.<ref name="f7119820a"/><ref name="sa110821"/><ref name="achr130830sb"/>
==Program and participants== [[File:Norman Spinrad at LoneStarCon3 2013.jpg|thumb|left|Author [[Norman Spinrad]] at LoneStarCon 3.]] The Guests of Honor were editor [[Ellen Datlow]], author [[James Gunn (author)|James Gunn]],<ref name="kcs130816"/> fan Willie Siros, author [[Norman Spinrad]], and artist [[Darrell K. Sweet]].<ref name="saen130823"/> (Although Sweet died in December 2011, he remained one of the convention's honored guests.) [[Paul Cornell]] served as Toastmaster for the event.<ref name="sa110821"/> Special guests were musician [[Leslie Fish]] and author [[Joe R. Lansdale]].<ref name="f7119820a"/>
Programming included hundreds of panels, screenings, concerts, signings, meetings, and other events on topics including women in aerospace, ''[[Doctor Who]]'', molecular gastronomy, the Vatican library, the histories of both science fiction and its fandom, plus readings of current work by attending authors. More than a dozen panels focused on Texas and its role in speculative fiction plus nearly as many on the life and work of author [[Robert E. Howard]].<ref name="achr130830sb"/>
The conventions several hundred program participants included authors [[Lois McMaster Bujold]], [[George R.R. Martin]], [[Jo Walton]], [[Howard Waldrop]], and [[Bradley Denton]] plus artists [[John Picacio]], [[Vincent Villafranca]], and NASA astronaut [[Cady Coleman]].<ref name="achr130830sb"/><ref name="achr130901lmb"/><ref name="sa130901"/><ref name="achr130830jw"/>
==Site selection== Committees who had announced bids to host the 2013 Worldcon included "[[Zagreb]] in 2013",<ref name="con100917"/> "Texas in 2013" ([[San Antonio]]), and a hoax bid for "[[Minneapolis]] in 5773". Only "Texas in 2013" qualified to be on the official ballot. As such, Texas' bid to host the Worldcon was formally unopposed and won in balloting among members of Renovation, the [[69th World Science Fiction Convention]], held in [[Reno, Nevada]], in August 2011.<ref name="lsc3pr1"/> With 760 valid ballots cast, Texas received 694 votes beating out No Preference with 25 and None of the Above with 14.<ref name="loc110822"/> Write-in candidates included Xerpes with 6, Minneapolis with 5, [[Denton, Texas|Denton]] with 5, Boston with 3, and a number of single-vote entries.<ref name="f7119820a"/>
== Awards == {{About-Hugos}}<ref name="hugo2013nom"/><ref name="mysa130723"/> ===Hugo Awards=== The base for the 2013 Hugo trophy was cast in bronze by artist [[Vincent Villafranca]] and depicts an astronaut and several aliens reading books while seated around the globe on which the traditional Hugo Award rocket has landed.<ref name="sa130821"/>
The Hugo ceremony was hosted by toastmaster [[Paul Cornell]] in the Grand Ballroom of the [[Marriott Rivercenter]] in downtown San Antonio.<ref name="sa130902"/> Presentations included the Big Heart Award to Tom Veal by [[First Fandom]], an ''[[wikt:in memoriam|in memoriam]]'' reel featuring music by [[Leslie Fish]], and a comedy routine by author [[Robert Silverberg]].<ref name="achr130903h"/> The proceedings were broadcast in partnership with [[Ustream]] but technical issues on-site kept the entire ceremony from being broadcast live.<ref name="sa130901"/><ref name="nyt130902"/>

==Masquerade== The LoneStarCon3 masquerade was held on Friday, 31 August with 29 entrants.<ref name="Silver">{{cite web|url=https://www.sfsite.com/news/2013/09/04/worldcon-masquerade-winners/|work=SF Site|title=Worldcon Masquerade Winners|first=Steven|last=Silver|date=September 4, 2013|accessdate=2017-05-19}}</ref> The masquerade director was Jill Eastlake and the master of ceremonies was [[Paul Cornell]].<ref name="Glyer">{{cite web|url=http://file770.com/?p=14429|title=LoneStarCon 3 Masquerade Winners|work=[[File 770]]|date=September 4, 2013|first=Mike|last=Glyer|authorlink=Mike Glyer|accessdate=2017-05-19}}</ref> The judges were John O'Halloran, [[Pierre Pettinger]] and [[Sandy Pettinger]] for performance; and [[John Hertz (fan)|John Hertz]] and [[Michele Weinstein]] for workmanship.<ref name="Silver" /><ref name="Glyer" />

==Future site selection==
===2015 Worldcon=== Three committees announced bids and qualified to be on the site selection ballot for the [[73rd World Science Fiction Convention]]: "[[Helsinki]] in 2015" to be held August 6–10, 2015,<ref name="gv120903"/> "[[Spokane, Washington|Spokane]] in 2015" to be held August 19–23, 2015,<ref name="fss111030"/> and "[[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]] in 2015" to be held September 2–6, 2015.<ref name="lscsite"/><ref name="seat141121">{{cite news |first=Tom |last=Sowa |newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]] |location=[[Seattle, WA]] |title=Spokane to host 2015 World Science Fiction Convention |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/outdoors/2025071133_spokanescificonventionxml.html |date=November 21, 2014 |accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> The first contested Worldcon selection since the 2006 vote for the [[66th World Science Fiction Convention|2008 Worldcon]] site saw active campaigning and drew celebrity endorsements.<ref name="grrm130813"/><ref name="fog130813"/>
Spokane won the site selection contest on the third round of ballot counting in Australian-style [[preferential ballot]]ing.<ref name="cnw130901sg"/> Spokane finished with 645 votes, gaining a majority over Helsinki with 610.<ref name="fss130831is"/> Orlando was dropped in the second round with 307 votes and "none of the above" had been eliminated in the first round.<ref name="les130901am"/> Spokane's Worldcon is named "[[Sasquan]]".<ref name="seat141121"/>
===2014 NASFiC=== Two committees announced bids and qualified to be on the site selection ballot for the 2014 [[North American Science Fiction Convention]] (NASFiC): "[[Detroit]] in 2014" to be held July 17–20, 2014, and "[[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] in 2014" to be held July 30–August 3, 2014.<ref name="lscsite"/> Detroit's bid was certified as the winner with 231 votes over Phoenix with 210 votes.<ref name="fss130831nr"/> Detroit needed at least 223 votes to win in the first round, based on the total of 453 valid votes cast.<ref name="les130901am"/> Detroit's NASFiC is named "[[Detcon1]]".<ref name="fss130831nr"/>

'''Abu 'Isa''' (also known as '''''Ovadiah''''', '''Ishaq ibn Ya'qub al-Isfahani''', '''Isaac ibn Jacob al-Isfahani''') was a self-proclaimed [[Prophet#Judaism|Jewish prophet]] sometime in the 8th century AD in [[Persia]] and the leader of a short-lived revolt. Proclaimed by some of his followers to be the [[Messiah in Judaism|Messiah]], Abu Isa himself never made such claims or inferences. He seems to have allied himself with Sunbadh after the assassination of Abu Muslim in 755 ad. His forces fought Caliph Al Mansur army at Rayy only to be defeated and Abu Isa fell in this battle.
==Dating issues== The dating of Abu Isa's career has been disputed since the Middle Ages. The two main sources for information of him are [[Jacob Qirqisani|Qirqisani]], a Jewish [[Karaite Judaism|Karaite]] historian; and [[Muhammad al-Shahrastani|Shahrastani]], who wrote an extensive guide to Jewish sects over the ages. Qirqisani places the events in the reign of the [[Umayyad]] [[Caliph]] [[Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan|Abd al-Malik]] (685 - 705 CE) while Shahrastani says it began under the reign of [[Marwan II]] (744 - 750) on through to [[Al-Mansur]] (d. 775). Qirqisani's dates place Abu Isa's uprising during Umayyad clashes with the [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantines]] which would coincide with Messianic stories of the battle between [[Gog and Magog]] and place it early enough to influence [[Karaite Judaism|Karaism]]; Shahrastani's would put the revolt at the end of the Umayyad Dynasty and thus at a pivotal point of upheaval in the [[Muslim history|Muslim world]].<ref name="Friedlaender">Israel Friedlaender Shiitic Elements in Jewish Sectarianism ''Jewish Quarterly Review'' Oct 1910</ref><ref name="Wasserstrom">Steven Wasserstrom ''Between Muslim and Jew'' Princeton University Press 1995</ref> Both are plausible and there is no direct Isawite documentation.
The Turkish scholar Halil Ibrahim Bulut in 2004 has shown that Shahrastani's 'Abbasid date is more likely.<ref>Halil Ibrahim Bulut, "ISEVIYYE (Islam Dunyasinda Ortaya Cikan Ilk Yahudi Mezhebi)", Ekev Academic Review, 8.18 (Jan. 2004) 297-318</ref>
==Beliefs== Abu Isa believed that he was the last of five heralds from God announcing the imminent arrival of the [[messiah]]. Never did he claim to be the Messiah himself, but some of his followers felt that he would return after his death and bring the [[End Times]]. He made some minor alterations to the general set of [[Rabbinic literature|Rabbinic laws]] and his followers became [[asceticism|ascetic]] in their manners. The most radical of the Isawite beliefs was the acceptance of both [[Jesus]] and [[Muhammad]] as true prophets, but only to their own peoples. *Other alterations included: **Banning of the consumption of [[wine]] and [[meat]] at certain times; **Sunnah [[Jewish prayers|prayers]] to 7 or 10 depending on the source<ref>Israel Friedlaender Shiitic Elements in Jewish Sectarianism ''Jewish Quarterly Review'' Oct 1912</ref> (in addition to the standard 3); **Affirmation of the Shammai stance on [[divorce]]; **Belief that Alnabi is a collection of [[rabbi|Hakham]]s;<ref>Bulut, 301-2</ref>
The ban on meat is actually a [[Talmud]]ic reference to not eating meat in exile, while the additional prayers are usually explained by noting [[Psalms|Psalm]] 119:164.
==Miracles== Two major [[miracle]]s are attributed to Abu Isa. The first stems from his writings, as he was known to his followers as nothing but an illiterate tailor before he was touched with prophecy. He is said to have thus produced the works that outline the beliefs above and herald the coming of the [[Messianic age]]. The other is during the revolt itself when he defended his followers from the Caliphate's forces behind a line drawn on the ground with a [[Myrtus|myrtle]] branch, at which point he rode out and singlehandedly defeated the first assault by the Muslims.
==Possible connection to Shi'ism==
The arrival of Abu Isa comes at an interesting point in the history of the Jews and the Muslims. Regardless of the which dates are true, each could be seen as during the rise of the radical [[Shi'a Islam|Shi'a]] movements in Islam. With the center of these movements being Iraq and later Persia, it should come as no surprise that the other [[ahl al-kitab]] or "People of the Book" might be influenced. Some Jews actually saw the coming of the Arabs as the [[apocalypse]] that would usher in the new age, but there are distinctive influences that can be noted in this movement from Shi'ism. The idea of the illiterate prophet is equated with the story of Muhammad and his receiving of the [[Qur'an]] while the idea of a chain of prophets is notably similar to the Imams and the foreseen coming of the [[Mahdi]]. Scholars disagree to what degree Shi'ism affected Abu Isa or whether Shi'ism was at the same time developing and incorporating Jewish elements.<ref name="Friedlaender"/><ref name="Wasserstrom"/> However, issues with this include that Shi'a reject the belief Muhammad was unlettered, Imams [[ismah|are infallible]], that Shi'ism did not expect the immediate return of al-Mahdi, and that [[Iraq]] and [[Iran]] were not primarily Shi'a until a few centuries ago.
==See also== *[[Jewish Messiah claimants]]

{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=March 2015}} {{primary sources|date=March 2015}} }} {{Infobox award | name = Best Illusion of the Year Contest | image = The Best Illusion of the Year Contest.gif | alt = | caption = | description = Contributions that promote public understanding of illusory perception and cognition | presenter = [[Neural Correlate Society]] | country = United States | year = 2005 | website = {{url|illusionoftheyear.com}} }} The '''Best Illusion of the Year Contest''' is an annual recognition of the world's illusion creators awarded by the [[Neural Correlate Society]].{{cite web|url=http://illusionoftheyear.com/about-the-contest/|title=About the Contest|accessdate=30 March 2014}} The contest was created in 2005 by professors [[Susana Martinez-Conde]]{{cite web|url=http://smc.neuralcorrelate.com|title=The Martinez-Conde Lab|accessdate=30 March 2014}} and [[Stephen Macknik]]{{cite web|url=http://macknik.neuralcorrelate.com|title=The Stephen Macknik Lab|accessdate=30 March 2014}} as part of the European conference on Visual Perception in [[A Coruña |La Coruna, Spain]].{{cite web|url=http://www.visionsciences.org/satellite_events.htm |title=Vision Sciences Society Satellite Events |accessdate=30 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131008054016/http://www.visionsciences.org/satellite_events.htm |archivedate= 8 October 2013 |df= }} It has since transitioned to an online contest where everyone in the world is invited to [http://illusionoftheyear.com/about-the-contest/submission-instructions/ submit illusions] and vote for the winner. The contest decides on the most impressive [[perceptual or cognitive illusion]] of the year (unpublished, or published no earlier than the year prior to the most recent competition). An illusion is a perceptual or cognitive experience that does not match the physical reality (i.e. the perception of motion where no such motion physically exists). As human experience is generated indirectly by brain mechanisms that interact with the physical reality, the study of illusions offers insight into the neural bases of perception and cognition. The community includes [[neuroscientists]], [[ophthalmologists]], [[neurologists]], and [[visual artists]] that create illusions to help discover the neural underpinnings of illusory perception. The Best Illusion of the Year Contest consists of three stages: submission, initial review, and voting of winners. The initial review is conducted by a panel of judges who are world experts in the science, art, and science education. The judge panel narrows the submissions to the Top Ten finalists, and viewers from all over the world can vote for the winner online. The top three winners receive cash awards. == Neural Correlate Society == The Neural Correlate Society (NCS) is a [[Nonprofit organization|nonprofit]] 501(c)3 organization that promotes research into the [[neural bases]] of perception and cognition.{{cite web|url=http://www.neuralcorrelate.com/|title=Neural Correlate Society|accessdate=30 March 2014}} The organization serves a community of [[neuroscientists]], [[ophthalmologists]], [[neurologists]], and [[artists]] who use a variety of methods to help discover the underpinnings of the human experience. The NCS hosts a variety of events, including the Best Illusion of the Year Contest, that highlight important new discoveries to the public. == Champions of Illusion == == The Illusions == === Award Recipients === The following table details the first, second, and third place recipients from each year of the contest since its inception. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! First Place !! Second Place !! Third Place |- | 2005{{cite web|url=http://illusionoftheyear.com/cat/top-10-finalists/2005/|title=Top Ten Finalists from 2005|accessdate=31 March 2014}} || Title: Motion Illusion Building Blocks
Created by: [[Arthur Shapiro (vision scientist)|Arthur Shapiro]] & Justin Charles || Title: Two-Stroke Apparent Motion
Created by: George Mather || Title: Elusive Arch
Created by: Dejan Todorović |- | 2006{{cite web|url=http://illusionoftheyear.com/cat/top-10-finalists/2006/|title=Top Ten Finalists from 2006|accessdate=31 March 2014}} || Title: The Freezing Rotation Illusion
Created by: Max Dürsteler || Title: The Infinite Regression Illusion
Created by: Peter Tse || Title:The Bar-Cross-Ellipse Illusion
Created by: Gideon Caplovitz & Peter Tse |- | 2007{{cite web|url=http://illusionoftheyear.com/cat/top-10-finalists/2007/|title=Top Ten Finalists from 2007|accessdate=31 March 2014}} || Title: The [[Leaning tower illusion|Leaning Tower Illusion]]

[[File:Congregation of Muslim, Tongi, Bangladesh.jpg|thumb|The huge Ijtema tent on the banks of the River Turag near Dhaka]] {{Islamic culture}} The '''Bishwa Ijtema''' ({{lang-bn|বিশ্ব ইজতেমা}}, meaning Global Congregation) is an annual gathering of [[Muslims]] in [[Tongi]], by the banks of the River [[Turag]], in the outskirts of [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]]. It is one of the [[List of largest peaceful gatherings in history|largest peaceful gatherings in the world]]. The Ijtema is a prayer meeting spread over three days, during which attending devotees perform daily prayers while listening to scholars reciting and explaining verses from the [[Quran]]. It culminates in the ''Akheri Munajat'', or the Final Prayer, in which millions of devotees raise their hands in front of Allah (God) and pray for [[world peace]].<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Akheri Munajat ends seeking world peace |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/country/biswa-ijtema-akheri-munajat-begins-199777 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=10 January 2016}}</ref> The Ijtema is considered a demonstration of Muslim unity, solidarity, mutual love and respect and an opportunity to reiterate their commitment to Islamic values.<ref name="banglapedia.org">{{cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Viswa_Ijtema|title=Viswa Ijtema - Banglapedia|publisher=}}</ref>
The Ijtema is non-political and therefore it draws people of all persuasion. It is attended by devotees from 150 countries.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/> The majority of its devotees come from across Bangladesh, the world's third largest Muslim majority country.
Speakers include Islamic scholars from various countries. Bishwa Ijtema is now the second largest Islamic gatherings with 5 million adherents <ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/>, after the [[Arba'een Pilgrimage]] (15-20 Million attendees),<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/arbaeen-pilgrimage-kerbala-shia-isis-defeat-muslims-thousands-killed-middle-east-iraq-najaf-a8046621.html|title=Free at last from Isis, millions of Muslims stage the greatest religious march in the world|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-GB}}</ref> surpassing the 2-3 million worshipers that perform the [[Hajj]] in Saudi Arabia (which is one of the five pillars of Islam for Muslims). The Bangladeshi Ijtema is a modern event where Muslim participation is voluntary.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-41102788|title=Two million Muslims begin Hajj pilgrimage in Mecca|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="telegraph.co.uk">{{cite news |last=Lemos |first=Eirini |date=7 January 2016 |title=What is the festival of Bishwa Ijtema and where is it held? |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/bangladesh/12088120/What-is-the-festival-of-Bishwa-Ijtema-and-where-is-it-held.html |newspaper=The Telegraph}}</ref><ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news |title=Muslims attend Bangladesh prayer |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4069759.stm |work=BBC News |date=5 December 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Muslims condemn Paris massacre at Bangladesh's mini-Hajj |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/muslims-condemn-paris-massacre-at-bangladeshs-mini-hajj/articleshow/45827695.cms |newspaper=The Economic Times |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=9 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Bangladesh Muslim festival ends |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1106912.stm |work=BBC News |date=8 January 2001}}</ref>
==Etymology== ''Ijtema'' is an [[Arabic]] word which means public gathering.<ref name="banglapedia.org"/> In [[Bengali language|Bengali]], the event is known as the "Bishwa Ijtema". ''Bishwa'' is a Bengali word which means world.
==Organization== The event is organized in January by the Bangladeshi branch of the [[Tablighi Jamaat]], an orthodox [[Sunni]] movement. The congregation takes place in an area which spans over five square kilometers in [[Tongi]], an outer suburb north of Dhaka.<ref name="banglapedia.org"/> An extensive [[tent]] is created in the area with the help of the [[Government of Bangladesh]]. Transport is provided by state-run companies, including [[Biman Bangladesh Airlines]], the [[Bangladesh Railway]] and the [[Bangladesh Road Transport Corporation]] (BRTC). The [[Bangladesh Armed Forces]] assists by arranging infrastructure. Despite the large number of devotees living within a confined space, generally there are very few problems of sanitation, cooking, and internal movements. It is believed to be possible because of the minimalist approach adopted by the devotees. Devotees reduce their own requirements and develop a respect for others' requirements. During the Final Prayer, huge crowds stretch from the Ijtema ground in Tongi into the Dhaka metropolitan area. Schools and offices are declared closed on the occasion.
==History== The Bengali Tabhlighi Jamaat movement started in Dhaka, [[East Bengal]] during the 1950s. The first Ijtemas were organized in [[Chittagong]] (1954) and [[Narayanganj]] (1958), followed by Ijtemas at the [[Ramna Race Course]] in Dhaka in 1960, 1962 and 1965.<ref name="banglapedia.org"/> Due to the increasing rate of participants, the government of East Pakistan allowed organizers to schedule the event annually by the River Turag in 1967.<ref name="banglapedia.org"/> Later, the government of Bangladesh allotted 160 acres of land for exclusively holding the event.<ref name="banglapedia.org"/>
==Number of devotees== In 2001, the number of attendees was 2 million.<ref name="banglapedia.org"/> In 2010, the number was 5 million.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/>
===Foreign devotees=== Estimates of foreign devotees stands at 20,000-50,000. They come from various regions, including the South Asian [[Subcontinent]], [[Russia]] and [[Central Asia]], [[Europe]], [[Southeast Asia]], the [[Middle East]], [[North Africa]] and the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Millions of Muslims gather in Bangladesh|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-bangladesh-religion-ijtema-idUKDHA10181920070202 |work=Reuters |date=2 February 2007}}</ref><ref name="banglapedia.org"/>
==Overcrowding and weather== Due to increasing overcrowding, the Ijtema was divided into two segments with an interval of seven days from 2010.<ref name="banglapedia.org"/> The first phase is allowed for devotees from 32 designated Bangladeshi districts. The second phase allows devotees from the remaining districts of the country.<ref name="banglapedia.org"/> Foreign devotees are allowed in both phases.
Due to increasing overcrowding, the Ijtema was divided into four segments from 2015. The first phase is allowed for devotees from 16 designated Bangladeshi districts. The second phase allows devotees from another 16 designated Bangladeshi districts. Devotees from the remaining 32 districts of the countrywill join next year.
In 2008, the event had to be cut short to only one day due to rain and cold weather which left three attendees dead.<ref>{{cite news |last=Sarkar |first=Kailash |date=26 January 2008 |title=Ijtema cut short for inclement weather |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-20631 |newspaper=The Daily Star}}</ref>
==Comparison with other Muslim gatherings== Unlike the [[Hajj]], the Ijtema is not one of the five pillars of Islam. Other major congregations in the Muslim world include [[Shia]] pilgrimages in [[Karbala]].
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Biswa Ijtema Dhaka Bangladesh.jpg|Devotees in the Dhaka metropolitan area File:Bishwa Iztema Dhaka Airport Rail Staion by Mayeenul Islam.JPG|Devotees at a Dhaka railway station File:Biswa Ijtema Dhaka Bangladesh 24012010.JPG|Devotees on the [[Bangladesh Railway]] </gallery>

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Bloody Mary (''South Park'')}} {{Infobox television episode | title = Bloody Mary | series = South Park | image = | caption = | season = 9 | episode = 14 | airdate = December 7, 2005 | director = [[Trey Parker]] | writer = Trey Parker | season_article = South Park (season 9) | episode_list = List of South Park episodes | prev = [[Free Willzyx]] | next = [[The Return of Chef]] }} "'''Bloody Mary'''" is the fourteenth episode in the [[South Park (season 9)|ninth season]] of the American animated television series ''[[South Park]]''. The 139th overall episode of the series, it originally aired on [[Comedy Central]] in the United States on December 7, 2005. In the episode, [[Randy and Sharon Marsh|Randy]] [[Driving under the influence|drives drunk]] and loses his driver's license. He is then ordered to attend [[Alcoholics Anonymous]] meetings, where he becomes convinced that his [[alcoholism]] is a potentially fatal disease. Meanwhile, a statue of the [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Virgin Mary]] starts bleeding "out its ass" and Randy believes that he can be "cured" if it bleeds on him.
== Plot == [[Stan Marsh|Stan]], [[Eric Cartman|Cartman]], [[Kyle Broflovski|Kyle]] and [[Ike Broflovski|Ike]] attend [[karate]] class while Stan's dad [[Randy and Sharon Marsh|Randy]] goes for a couple of drinks. After class, an inebriated Randy drives the boys home, but he gets pulled over and arrested for [[drunk driving]]. Randy gets his license revoked and is ordered to perform community service and to attend [[Alcoholics Anonymous]], where he's introduced to the [[twelve-step program]], which leads him to believe he is powerless to control his drinking and that alcoholism is a disease. Randy, whom Stan describes as a "[[hypochondriac]]", then begins to drink more, since he has decided that he is in fact powerless to control it and cannot stop. Meanwhile, a statue of the [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Virgin Mary]] starts to bleed "out its ass" and people begin to flock around it to find a cure for their diseases. Randy believes it can cure his disease.
Randy has Stan drive him to the church where the statue is, and after [[cutting in line]], arguing that his "disease" is worse than that of others, he is drenched in the holy blood. He jumps up and declares that he will not drink any more, and abstains from alcohol for five days.
[[Pope Benedict XVI]] comes to investigate, and discovers that the blood is not actually coming from the statue's [[anus]], but from its [[vagina]]. Since "[[Menstrual cycle|chicks bleed out their vaginas all the time]]", this is no miracle. Randy, disappointed, realizes that [[God]] did not "heal" him. At first he again declares himself powerless, and most of the other recovering alcoholics agree and rush to the bar. But Stan follows Randy and convinces him that if God did not help him, then he must have managed to stop by himself.
Randy declares that he will never drink again. Stan objects to this too, claiming that if Randy completely avoids drinking, then drinking is still controlling his life and he needs to figure out how to live in moderation. Randy puts Stan on his shoulders and walks home while the two discuss how much drinking would be proper.
==Production== [[Trey Parker]] and [[Matt Stone]] reveal on the DVD commentary for this episode that they had wanted to do an episode involving [[Alcoholics Anonymous]] meetings for "a long time", but could never get it right.<ref name="Commentary">''South Park The Complete Ninth Season'' DVD commentary for "Bloody Mary". [[Trey Parker]] and [[Matt Stone]].</ref>
The bleeding statue idea came from [[Anne Garefino]], a producer on the show, and was inspired by the real life phenomenon of "[[weeping statue]]s", unusual occurrences where statues would unexplainably "bleed" some sort of liquid via supernatural means, usually from the eyes.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} The crew were discussing the idea of having this happen in an episode but felt it needed to be something more outlandish than the eyes. Garefino then came up with the idea of having the statue "shit blood all over the pope's face". Parker and Stone loved the twist, even if it meant the episode would likely draw far more controversy than normal.<ref name="Commentary"/>
The scene in which Randy gets arrested for drunk driving is based on a near identical experience that Parker had with his father when he was nine years-old.<ref name="Commentary"/>
==Controversy== The episode was aired on December 7, 2005, which is the eve of the [[Feast of the Immaculate Conception]], a Catholic observance related specifically to the Virgin Mary. "Bloody Mary" was considered a very controversial episode, even by ''South Park'' standards. [[Catholic League (U.S.)|The Catholic League]] demanded an apology and that the episode "be permanently retired and not be made available on [[DVD]]" and that [[Joseph A. Califano, Jr.]], a board member of [[Viacom]] (the parent company of [[Comedy Central]]) and a practicing Catholic, issue a personal statement.<ref> {{cite press release| title=Virgin Mary defiled on "South Park"| publisher=Catholic League (U.S.)| date=2005-12-08| url=http://www.catholicleague.org/05press_releases/quarter%204/051208_south_park.htm| accessdate=2006-07-06| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070718164613/http://www.catholicleague.org/05press_releases/quarter%204/051208_south_park.htm| archivedate=2007-07-18| df=}}</ref> Califano did later release a statement calling the episode an "appalling and disgusting portrayal of the Virgin Mary", and pledged to have it reviewed by Viacom's president and CEO, [[Tom Freston]]. Bishop [[William Skylstad]], president of the [[United States Conference of Catholic Bishops]], sent a letter to Freston saying the network showed "extreme insensitivity" when it aired the episode.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://cathnews.acu.edu.au/512/119.php|title=Bishops' president blasts ''South Park'' episode|date=2005-12-21|publisher=Church Resources|accessdate=2006-07-06}}</ref> When Comedy Central re-aired all episodes of Season 9 on December 28, 2005, "Bloody Mary" was absent from the broadcast. Comedy Central responded to e-mail inquiries about the fate of the episode with the assurance that "Bloody Mary" has not been retired and would not be pulled from the DVD release.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boingboing.net/2006/01/09/south_park_bloody_ma.html|title=South Park "Bloody Mary" an immaculate deletion, says Comedy Central|date=2006-01-09|publisher=BoingBoing|accessdate=2006-07-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060426221954/http://www.boingboing.net/2006/01/09/south_park_bloody_ma.html|archivedate=2006-04-26|df=}}</ref> Screen captures from the episode on Comedy Central's press site and the ''South Park'' section of comedycentral.com are absent.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.eonline.com/News/Items/0,1,18055,00.html?tnews|title="South Park" Parked by Complaints?|date=2005-12-29|author=Sarah Hall|publisher=[[E!]]|accessdate=2006-07-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060427031803/http://www.eonline.com/News/Items/0%2C1%2C18055%2C00.html?tnews|archivedate=2006-04-27|df=}}</ref>
In February 2006, leaders from the New Zealand Catholic Bishops' Conference, the Council of Christians and Muslims, and other religious groups together lobbied media conglomerate [[CanWest Global Communications|CanWest]] to stop a planned airing of the episode in [[New Zealand]] on the music channel [[C4 (New Zealand)|C4]]. The network rejected the plea and said the episode would air as planned.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/stuff/0,2106,3570043a1869,00.html |title=South Park controversy continues |date=2006-02-13 |author=Kristian South |publisher=Sunday News |accessdate=2006-07-06 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070103014218/http://www.stuff.co.nz/stuff/0,2106,3570043a1869,00.html |archivedate=2007-01-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/category/story.cfm?c_id=100&ObjectID=10369212|title=TV chief rejects bishops' boycott call over 'tasteless' cartoon|date=2006-02-20|author=Martin Johnston|author2=Errol Kiong|publisher=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|accessdate=2006-07-06}}</ref> Leading Catholic bishops then called for a [[boycott]] of C4 and its sister network [[TV3 (New Zealand)|TV3]]. CanWest again resisted and aired the episode sooner than planned to take advantage of the media attention. New Zealand's [[Prime Minister of New Zealand|Prime Minister]] [[Helen Clark]] issued a statement saying the episode sounded "revolting", but that the network was free to air it. One advertiser withdrew their ads from CanWest's networks. Catholic group Family Life International set up a website for boycotting CanWest's other advertisers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4735216.stm|title=Catholics urge South Park boycott|date=2006-02-21|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=2006-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/story.cfm?c_id=1&ObjectID=10369513|title=Church outrage as cartoon to air tonight|date=2006-02-22|author=Errol Kiong|author2=Martin Johnston|publisher=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|accessdate=2006-07-06}}</ref> Another company named C4 Productions, which has no links to the C4 music channel, applied for a court order on the eve of the airing to stop the episode, citing damage to its business because it thought people would link it to the channel. The judge ruled against the order.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/stuff/0,2106,3581315a10,00.html|title=Protests fail to stop Mary show|date=2006-02-23|publisher=[[The Dominion Post (Wellington)|The Dominion Post]]|accessdate=2006-07-06|author=Rebecca Palmer}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> C4 aired the episode on February 22, 2006 and drew 210,000 viewers, six times ''South Park'''s normal audience for the channel.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/stuff/0,2106,3582068a1860,00.html|title=Bloody Mary show attracts six times usual audience|date=2006-02-23|publisher=[[NZPA]]|accessdate=2006-07-06}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> After receiving 102 formal complaints from viewers, the network issued a statement a month later saying "C4 acknowledges the strength of feeling in relation to the programme, and we sincerely apologize for any offence taken."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/stuff/0,2106,3613840a11,00.html|title=Apology over 'Bloody Mary' programme|date=2006-03-24|publisher=[[The Dominion Post (Wellington)|The Dominion Post]]|accessdate=2006-07-06|author=Rebecca Palmer}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
{{wikinews|35 South Park complaints not upheld, New Zealand}} In June 2006 complaints received by New Zealand's Broadcasting Standards Authority (BSA) were rejected: The airing of the show was found to not be in breach of broadcasting standards. According to the BSA, "[b]ut showing disrespect does not amount to the sort of vicious or vitriolic attack normally associated with the denigration standard." They also said the episode was "of such a farcical, absurd and unrealistic nature that it did not breach standards of good taste and decency in the context in which it was offered."<ref> {{cite press release |title=BSA Releases ''South Park'' Decision |publisher=Broadcast Standards Authority |date=2006-06-30 |url=http://www.bsa.govt.nz/pressreleases/2006-06-30.htm |accessdate=2006-07-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060813150807/http://www.bsa.govt.nz/pressreleases/2006-06-30.htm |archivedate=2006-08-13 |df= }}</ref> New Zealand Catholic bishops have decided to appeal the decision.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/story.cfm?c_id=1&ObjectID=10390950|title=Catholic bishops to appeal South Park decision|date=2006-07-12|accessdate=2006-07-12|work=The New Zealand Herald}}</ref>
In February 2006, [[Archdiocese of Melbourne|Archbishop]] [[Denis Hart]] in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] wrote to television network [[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]] asking them not to air the episode. The network's programming director originally rejected the request, but later decided to postpone the episode citing the controversy over the [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy|''Jyllands-Posten'' Muhammad cartoons]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cathnews.com/news/602/92.php |title=Muslim cartoon controversy prompts SBS reversal on ''South Park'' |date=2006-02-16 |publisher=Church Resources |accessdate=2006-07-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060825194309/http://www.cathnews.com/news/602/92.php |archivedate=August 25, 2006 }}</ref> The episode was, however, shown on [[The Comedy Channel]], on August 30, 2006.{{cn|date=December 2015}}
On March 14, 2006, [[Rob Corddry]], reporting on Comedy Central's own ''[[The Daily Show with Jon Stewart]]'', said:
:Christianity has evolved and matured. No longer do they stone people to death for blasphemy. Now they write a lot of letters to advertisers. Even a secular, atheistic, [[morally bankrupt]] entity like Comedy Central can be affected. Just ask Matt Stone and Trey Parker, creators of ''South Park'', whose recent episode entitled "Bloody Mary" was pulled after a single airing. Now obviously [we at] Comedy Central can't show you that offensive material.
The ''South Park'' clips shown while Corddry spoke included several scenes of seemingly offensive material (fornicating cats, a man vomiting and then falling in his own vomit, [[Butters Stotch|Butters]] viewing a man being sodomized, etc.) but there was nothing from the "Bloody Mary" episode.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cc.com/video-clips/y1rfkf/the-daily-show-with-jon-stewart-this-week-in-god---blasphemy-edition|title=This Week In God - Blasphemy Edition|date=2006-03-14|publisher=Comedy Central|accessdate=2017-12-03}}</ref>
Like the "[[Trapped in the Closet (South Park)|Trapped in the Closet]]" episode, "Bloody Mary" did return to the air, appearing on August 2, 2006.

revision.text:
The '''Curse of the Billy Goat''' was a sports-related curse that was supposedly placed on the [[Chicago Cubs]] [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) franchise in 1945, by [[Billy Goat Tavern]] owner William Sianis. The curse lasted 71 years, from 1945 to 2016. Because the odor of his pet [[goat]], named Murphy, was bothering other fans, Sianis was asked to leave [[Wrigley Field]], the Cubs' home ballpark, during game 4 of the [[1945 World Series]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ferraro|first1=Michael X.|last2=Veneziano|first2=John|title=Numbelivable!|page=119|publisher=Triumph Books|location=Chicago, Illinois|year=2007|isbn=978-1-57243-990-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Newman|first=Mark|title=Will the Cubs break the Curse of the Billy Goat in the 'Year of the Goat?'|url=http://m.mlb.com/cutfour/2015/02/19/109699372/will-the-cubs-break-the-curse-of-the-billy-goat-in-the-year-of-the-goat|publisher=[[MLB Advanced Media]]|website=MLB.com|date=February 19, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221081250/http://m.mlb.com/cutfour/2015/02/19/109699372/will-the-cubs-break-the-curse-of-the-billy-goat-in-the-year-of-the-goat|archivedate=February 21, 2015|accessdate=May 1, 2018|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Outraged, Sianis allegedly declared, "Them Cubs, they ain't gonna win no more," which had been interpreted to mean that the Cubs would never win another [[National League]] (NL) [[List of National League pennant winners|pennant]] (at least for the remainder of Sianis's life).
The Cubs lost the 1945 World Series to the [[Detroit Tigers]], and did not win a [[List of World Series champions|World Series championship]] again until 2016. After the incident with Sianis and Murphy, the Cubs did not play in the World Series for the next 71 years until, on the 46th anniversary of Billy Sianis's death,<ref name="SianisLegacy">{{cite news|title=Celebrity Deaths: William Sianis and the Curse of the Billy Goat|url=http://www.legacy.com/news/celebrity-deaths/article/william-sianis-and-the-curse-of-the-billy-goat|website=Legacy.com|accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref> the "curse" was broken when they defeated the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] 5–0 in game 6 of the [[2016 National League Championship Series]] to win the NL pennant.<ref name="CubsWinNLPennant">{{cite news|last1=Gurnick|first=Ken|last2=Muskat|first2=Carrie|title=Wait of the World: Cubs win NL pennant!|url=https://www.mlb.com/news/cubs-beats-dodgers-in-game-6-to-win-nl-pennant/c-206880270|publisher=MLB Advanced Media|website=MLB.com|date=October 23, 2016|accessdate=October 25, 2016}}</ref> The Cubs then defeated the [[American League]] (AL) [[List of American League pennant winners|champion]] [[Cleveland Indians]] 8–7 in 10 innings in game 7 to win the [[2016 World Series]].<ref name="CubsWinWorldSeries">{{cite news|last1=Bastian|first1=Jordan|last2=Muskat|first2=Carrie|title=Cubs are heavy wait champions!|url=https://www.mlb.com/news/chicago-cubs-win-2016-world-series/c-207938228|publisher=MLB Advanced Media|website=MLB.com|date=November 2, 2016|accessdate=November 3, 2016}}</ref>
==Origins of the curse== The exact nature of Sianis's curse differs in various accounts of the incident. Some state that he declared that no World Series games would ever again be played at Wrigley Field, while others believe that his ban was on the Cubs appearing in the World Series, making no mention of a specific venue. Sianis’s family claims that he dispatched a telegram to team owner [[Philip K. Wrigley]] which read, “You are going to lose this World Series and you are never going to win another World Series again. You are never going to win a World Series again because you insulted my goat.”<ref name="Selzer2014">{{cite book|author=Adam Selzer|title=Chronicles of Old Chicago: Exploring the History and Lore of the Windy City|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SPEiBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA156|date=1 July 2014|publisher=Museyon Inc|isbn=978-0-9846334-8-7|page=156}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Avila|first=Michael|title=Are the Chicago Cubs Really Cursed?|url=http://www.livescience.com/32802-are-the-chicago-cubs-really-cursed.html|website=[[LiveScience]]|date=September 2, 2010|accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref>
Whatever the truth, the Cubs were up two games to one in the 1945 Series, but ended up losing Game 4, as well as the best-of-seven series, four games to three. The curse was immortalized in newspaper columns over the years, particularly by syndicated columnist [[Mike Royko]]. The curse gained widespread attention during the 2003 postseason, when [[Fox Major League Baseball|Fox]] television commentators played it up during the Cubs-[[Miami Marlins|Marlins]] matchup in the [[2003 National League Championship Series|National League Championship Series]] (NLCS).<ref>{{cite video|title=Major League Baseball on Fox: Game 6 of 2003 National League Championship Series|publisher=Fox Sports|date=October 14, 2003|medium=television}}</ref> According to an account in the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times|Chicago Sun]]'' of October 7, 1945, the goat was turned away at the gate, and Sianis left the goat tied to a stake in a parking lot and went into the game alone. There was mention of a lawsuit that day, but no mention of a curse.
Between that 1908 triumph, which was the Cubs' second world championship (they'd also won the Series in [[1907 World Series|1907]] to become baseball's first back-to-back winners as well as the first franchise to appear in three consecutive World Series), and 1945, the first year of the alleged Billy Goat curse, the Cubs won the National League pennant six times but failed to win the Series: in [[1910 World Series|1910]], in [[1918 World Series|1918]] (won by the [[Boston Red Sox]] who themselves would soon become victims of an alleged baseball [[Curse of the Bambino|curse]] and not win another Series for 86 years), in [[1929 World Series|1929]], in [[1932 World Series|1932]] (known for [[Babe Ruth's called shot]] at Wrigley Field), in [[1935 World Series|1935]] (a re-match of the 1908 series against the [[Detroit Tigers]], with the Tigers winning this time, their first Series triumph in five appearances dating back to the early 1900s), and in [[1938 World Series|1938]].
==Alleged curse incidents== On September 9, 1969, at [[Shea Stadium]], the Cubs played the [[New York Mets]] in a critical pennant race game. A stray [[black cat]] walked between Cubs captain [[Ron Santo]], who was on deck, and the Cubs dugout. The Mets would pull ahead of the Cubs in that series and eventually win both the newly formed NL East and the 1969 [[World Series]].<ref>{{cite news|title=On Friday the 13th, let's revisit the Cubs' 'Black Cat Game'|url=https://www.mlb.com/cut4/remembering-the-cubs-black-cat-game-on-friday-the-13th/c-177833950|publisher=MLB Advanced Media|date=May 13, 2016|accessdate=November 3, 2016}}</ref>
In 1984, the Cubs’ postseason appearance was dashed by the [[San Diego Padres]]. The Cubs were victorious in the first two games of the best-of-five series. However, in game five, first baseman [[Leon Durham]] let a ground ball get past his allegedly wet glove in the bottom of the seventh inning. The Padres went on to score four runs to win the game and the series.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mitchell|first=Fred|title=Durham doesn't think much of error in '84 playoffs|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-05-04/sports/ct-spt-0505-mitchell-cubs-leon-durham-chicago--20120505_1_cubs-fans-mookie-wilson-error|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=May 4, 2012|accessdate=November 3, 2016}}</ref>
In 1989, the Cubs won 93 games and faced the [[San Francisco Giants]] in the [[National League Championship Series]], now a best-of-seven series. After splitting the first two games at home, the Cubs headed to the Bay Area, where despite holding a lead at some point in each of the next three games, bullpen meltdowns and managerial blunders ultimately led to three straight losses.
In 1998, behind NL MVP [[Sammy Sosa]], the Cubs won the Wild Card after winning a tiebreaker game vs the Giants. However, they were swept in the [[National League Division Series]] by the [[Atlanta Braves]].
On October 14, 2003, in the eighth [[inning]] of Game 6 of the NLCS, with Chicago ahead 3–0 and holding a three games to two lead in the [[Playoff format#Best-of-seven playoff|best of seven series]], several spectators attempted to catch a [[foul ball]] off the bat of Marlins second baseman [[Luis Castillo (baseball)|Luis Castillo]]. One of the fans, [[Steve Bartman]], reached for the ball, deflecting it and disrupting a potential catch by Cubs outfielder [[Moisés Alou]]. If Alou had caught the ball, it would have been the second out in the inning and the Cubs would have been just four outs away from winning their first [[List of National League pennant winners|National League pennant]] since [[1945 Chicago Cubs season|1945]]. Instead, the Cubs ended up surrendering eight runs in the inning and losing the game, 8–3. When they were eliminated in the seventh game the next day, the incident was seen as the "first domino" in the turning point of the series.<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|title=Baseball fan feels Chicago's fury|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/3200582.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]]|website=BBCNews.com|date=October 17, 2003|accessdate=July 9, 2008}}</ref>
The Cubs won their division in both [[2007 Chicago Cubs season|2007]] and [[2008 Chicago Cubs season|2008]], but were swept in the NLDS both years by the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]] and [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] respectively.
In 2015, the Cubs finished second in the National League Wild Card race and defeated the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] in the [[2015 National League Wild Card Game|Wild Card Game]] and the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] in the [[2015 National League Division Series|NLDS]] to advance to the [[2015 National League Championship Series|NLCS]] against the [[New York Mets]]. However, the Cubs batted an NLCS record low of .164 and lost the series in a 4-game sweep. (The Cubs thus became the first team ever to get swept in a playoff series by a team they swept in their regular season series.)
Sianis's goat was named Murphy. In the [[2015 National League Championship Series]], this was referenced by fans of the [[New York Mets]], who joked that [[Daniel Murphy (baseball)|Daniel Murphy]], the Mets second baseman and [[2015 National League Championship Series | series MVP]], was "not the first GOAT (Greatest of All Time, in reference to Murphy's postseason heroics to that point) named Murphy to keep the Cubs out of the World Series".<ref>{{cite news|last=Berg|first=Ted|title=The Cubs' infamously exiled billy goat was also named 'Murphy'|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2015/10/chicago-cubs-daniel-murphy-new-york-mets-billy-goat-nlcs-mlb|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=October 18, 2015|accessdate=July 3, 2016}}</ref>
==Attempts to break the curse== Prior to his death on October 22, 1970, Billy Sianis himself attempted to lift the curse. Sam Sianis, his nephew, has gone to Wrigley Field with a goat multiple times in attempts to break the curse, including on [[Opening Day]] in 1984 and again in 1989, both years in which the Cubs went on to win their division. In 1994, Sam Sianis went again, with a goat, to stop a home losing streak, and in 1998 for the [[1998 National League Wild Card tie-breaker game|Wild Card tie-breaker game]], which the Cubs won.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Billy Goat Curse|url=http://www.billygoattavern.com/legend/curse/|publisher=The World-Famous Billy Goat Tavern|date=August 14, 2015|accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref>
In 2003 (the [[Chinese zodiac|Chinese zodiac's]] [[Goat (zodiac)|Year of the Goat]]), a group of Cubs fans headed to [[Houston]] with a billy goat named "Virgil Homer" and attempted to gain entrance to [[Minute Maid Park]], home of the [[Houston Astros|Astros]], division rivals of the Cubs at the time.<ref>{{cite news|title=Woe is us ; A look at the curses|date=October 16, 2004|newspaper=USA Today|page=C2}}</ref> After they were denied entrance, they unfurled a scroll, read a verse and proclaimed they were "reversing the curse". The Cubs won the [[National League Central|division]] that year and then came within five outs of playing in the World Series, but were undone by the [[2003 Florida Marlins season|Florida Marlins]]' eight-run rally immediately following the [[Steve Bartman incident]]. The Cubs then lost the following game and with it the series. (The Marlins went on to win the [[2003 World Series|World Series]] against the [[New York Yankees]].) Further salting the wound, the Astros earned their first World Series berth [[2005 World Series|two years later]] and their crosstown rival the Chicago White Sox won the series.
On February 26, 2004, at the Harry Caray Restaurant in downtown Chicago, the Bartman baseball was electrocuted in an attempt to break the curse, leaving nothing but a heap of string behind.
In another bizarre twist, it was reported that a butchered goat was hung from the [[Harry Caray]] statue on October 3, 2007, to which ''[[The Chicago Sun-Times]]'' noted: "If the prankster intended to reverse the supposed billy goat curse with the stunt, it doesn't appear to have worked."<ref name=hung>{{cite news|last=Toomey|first=Shamus|title=Dead goat hung from Harry statue|newspaper=Chicago Sun-Times|date=October 6, 2007}}</ref> While the Cubs did win the NL Central division title in 2007 and 2008, they were swept in the first round of the postseason in both years: by the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]] in [[2007 National League Division Series|2007]] and the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] in [[2008 National League Division Series|2008]]. The elimination by Arizona came on October 6, the same date that the goat appeared at Wrigley Field in 1945.<ref>{{cite news|title=Castilla Back With Rockies In New Role|date=October 7, 2007|first=Barry|last=Svrluga|newspaper=Washington Post|page=D6}}</ref> The act was repeated before the home opener in 2009, this time a goat's butchered head being hung from the statue. The act was futile as the Cubs were eliminated from postseason contention on September 26, 2009.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sullivan|first=Paul|title=CUBS 6, GIANTS 2; Eliminating the negative; Late hot streak minus Bradley is positive, but Cards clinch anyway|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=September 27, 2009|page=9}}</ref>
In 2008, a Greek Orthodox priest sought to end the curse during the 2008 playoffs with a spraying of holy water in and around the Cubs dugout to no avail.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TnQZJbCrH5w|title=Priest Blesses Chicago Cubs Dugout With Holy Water|date=20 January 2009|work=YouTube}}</ref>
On April 1, 2011, a social enterprise called Reverse The Curse, dedicated to bringing innovations to poverty by giving goats to families in developing countries, was initiated.<ref>{{cite web|title=Reverse the Curse|url=http://www.reversethecursechicago.com/about|publisher=Reverse The Curse Chicago|date=August 14, 2015|accessdate=August 14, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150709001507/http://reversethecursechicago.com/about/|archivedate=July 9, 2015|df=}}</ref> The goats provide the family with milk, cheese, and alternative income to help lift them out of poverty. Reverse The Curse has expanded into reversing the "curses" that afflict the world's children in education and obesity.
On February 25, 2012, a group of five Chicago Cubs fans calling themselves ''Crack the Curse'' set out on foot from [[Mesa, Arizona]] (home to the Cubs' [[spring training]] facilities) to Wrigley Field. They brought along a goat named Wrigley whom they believed would be able to break the Curse of the Billy Goat upon arrival at Wrigley Field. Additionally, they attempted to raise $100,000 for the [[Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Stephen|title=Cubs fans and goat walk from Ariz. to Chicago to crack the team's curse|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/cubs-fans-and-goat-walk-from-ariz-to-chicago-to-crack-the-teams-curse/|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=May 29, 2012|accessdate=May 1, 2018}}</ref>
On April 10, 2013, a severed goat's head was delivered to the Cubs in a possible effort to lift the curse on the team. It was addressed to the club's owner [[Thomas S. Ricketts]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Brumfield|first=Ben|title=Severed goat's head at Wrigley Field mirrors curse on Chicago Cubs|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/04/11/justice/chicago-goat-curse/index.html|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=April 11, 2013|accessdate=October 26, 2015}}</ref>
On September 22, 2015, [[Patrick Bertoletti]], Tim Brown, [[Takeru Kobayashi]], [[Kevin Strahle]] and [[Bob Shoudt]] consumed a 40-pound goat in 13 minutes and 22 seconds at Taco in a Bag restaurant in Chicago.<ref>{{cite web|author=Fox News|title=Competitive eaters devour goat meat to break Cubs. However at the end the New York Mets beat the Cubs and loss the NL championship in 2015 (which later the Kansas City Royals win the World seeies of 2015.curse|url=https://nypost.com/2015/09/24/competitive-eaters-devour-goat-meat-to-break-chicago-cubs-curse/|newspaper=[[New York Post]]|date=September 24, 2015|accessdate=October 26, 2015}}</ref>
On October 7, 2016, the owners of The Chicago Diner, a local vegetarian eatery near Wrigley Field, teamed up with [[Farm Sanctuary]] to try to reverse the Curse of the Billy Goat by displaying posters in the windows at their locations. The posters feature a goat named Peanut who urges Chicagoans to “reverse the curse” by going meat-free.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Chicago Diner Teams Up With Farm Sanctuary to Reverse the Curse of the Billy Goat|url=http://www.farmsanctuary.org/media/2016-press-releases/chicago-diner-teams-up-with-farm-sanctuary-to-reverse-the-curse-of-the-billy-goat/|website=FarmSanctuary.org|date=October 7, 2016|access-date=May 1, 2018}}</ref>
==Former Cubs who won a World Series title elsewhere== {{see also|Ex-Cubs Factor}}
Another factor that may play a role in the curse is the number of players (42 of them are listed below) who won World Series titles after leaving the Cubs (known as the [[Ex-Cubs Factor]]). These players include [[Andy Pafko]] (who, coincidentally, played in the 1945 World Series as a member of the Cubs), [[Gene Baker]], [[Smoky Burgess]], [[Don Hoak]], [[Dale Long]], [[Lou Brock]] (whose first title was in {{wsy|1964}} after [[Brock for Broglio|a mid-season trade]] to the [[St. Louis Cardinals]]), [[Lou Johnson]], [[Jim Brewer]], [[Moe Drabowsky]], [[Don Cardwell]], [[Ken Holtzman]], [[Paul Noce]], [[Billy North]], [[Fred Norman]], [[Bill Madlock]], [[Manny Trillo]], [[Greg Gross]], [[Rick Monday]], [[Burt Hooton]], [[Bruce Sutter]], [[Willie Hernández]], [[Milt Wilcox]], [[Joe Niekro]], [[Dennis Eckersley]], [[Joe Carter]], [[Greg Maddux]], [[Joe Girardi]] (as both a player and a manager), [[José Vizcaíno]], [[Glenallen Hill]] (after his second stint with the Cubs; his title came in {{wsy|2000}} after a mid-season trade), [[Luis Gonzalez (outfielder)|Luis Gonzalez]], [[Mike Morgan (baseball)|Mike Morgan]], [[Mark Grace]], [[Mark Bellhorn]], [[Bill Mueller]], [[Scott Eyre]] (whose title came in {{wsy|2008}} after he had been traded from the Cubs during the season), [[Tom Gordon]], [[Matt Stairs]], [[Jamie Moyer]], [[Mark DeRosa]], [[Mike Fontenot]], [[Ryan Theriot]], [[Ángel Pagán]], and, in 2013, [[Ryan Dempster]]. [[Dontrelle Willis]] and [[Jon Garland]] were traded as minor leaguers (coincidentally, the former won a World Series ring with the Marlins team that defeated the Cubs in the 2003 NLCS). [[Tim Lincecum]], who went on to win three World Series titles, was originally drafted by the Cubs, but he did not sign with them.<ref>{{cite web|title=2003 First-Year Player Draft Tracker|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/draftday/search.jsp?sc=round&sp=48|publisher=MLB Advanced Media, LP|date=June 4, 2003|accessdate=August 14, 2015}}</ref>
==End of the curse== {{main article|2016 Chicago Cubs season|2016 World Series}} The Cubs ended the [[2016 Chicago Cubs season|2016 season]] with a {{Win-loss record|w=103|l=58}} ({{winpct|103|58}}) record. It was their first 100-win season since [[1935 Chicago Cubs season|1935]] ({{Win-loss record|w=100|l=54}}, {{winpct|100|54}}), their best since [[1910 Chicago Cubs season|1910]] ({{Win-loss record|w=104|l=50}}, {{winpct|104|50}}), and the sixth 100-win season in franchise history.
The Cubs won the [[2016 National League Championship Series|National League Championship Series]] (NLCS), their first pennant in 71 years, with a 5–0 shutout in Game 6 against the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] at [[Wrigley Field]] on October 22, 2016, the "curse" was broken on the 46th anniversary of Billy Sianis's death.<ref name="SianisLegacy" /><ref name="CubsWinNLPennant" />
[[File:The Chicago Cubs and the Cleveland Indians play Game 7 of the World Series at Progressive Field in Cleveland, Ohio, Nov. 2, 2016. (K.Farabaugh-VOA).jpg|thumb|The Chicago Cubs and Cleveland Indians play Game 7 of the [[2016 World Series]] in Cleveland on November 2, 2016. The Cubs won, ending their 108-year losing streak.]] [[File:2016-10-22 Cubs fans It is happening.jpg|thumb|Cubs fan sign before Game 6 of the [[2016 National League Championship Series]]]] In 2016, the Cubs won the World Series for the first time since 1908, ending the historic 108-year drought.
The Cubs beat the [[Cleveland Indians]] in the [[2016 World Series]] in seven games after trailing in the series 3 games to 1. They won game 7 by a score of 8–7 in 10 innings at [[Progressive Field]] in [[Cleveland|Cleveland, Ohio]].<ref name="CubsWinWorldSeries" />

{{refimprove|date=October 2015}}
The '''David P. Robbins Prize''' for papers reporting novel research in algebra, combinatorics, or discrete mathematics is awarded both by the [[American Mathematical Society]] (AMS) and by the [[Mathematical Association of America]] (MAA). The AMS award recognizes papers with a significant experimental component on a topic which is broadly accessible which provide a simple statement of the problem and clear exposition of the work. Papers eligible for the MAA award are judged on quality of research, clarity of exposition, and accessibility to undergraduates. Both awards consist of $5000 and are awarded once every three years. They are named in the honor of [[David P. Robbins]] and were established in 2005 by the members of his family.
==Winners (AMS Robbins Prize)== * 2019 : Roger Behrend, Ilse Fischer and Matjaž Konvalinka for their paper “Diagonally and antidiagonally symmetric alternating sign matrices of odd order,” published in 2017 in Advances in Mathematics (Vol. 315, pp. 324-365).<ref>http://www.ams.org/news?news_id=4726</ref> * 2016 : [[Manuel Kauers]], [[Christoph Koutschan]] and [[Doron Zeilberger]] for their paper "Proof of George Andrews's and David Robbins's q-TSPP conjecture”,<ref>[http://www.koutschan.de/data/qtspp Koutschan, Kauers, Zeilberger: Proof of George Andrews's and David Robbins's q-TSPP conjecture]</ref> [[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]] (PNAS) 108(6) pp. 2196–2199. * 2013 : [[Alexander Razborov]] for his paper "On the minimal density of triangles in graphs”,<ref>[http://www.mi.ras.ru/~razborov/triangles.pdf Razborov: On the minimal density of triangles in graphs]</ref> [[Combinatorics, Probability and Computing]] 17(4):603–618, 2008. * 2010 : [[Ileana Streinu]] for her paper "Pseudo-triangulations, rigidity and motion planning”, [[Discrete & Computational Geometry]] 34(4):587–635, 2005. * 2007 : [[Samuel P. Ferguson]] and [[Thomas C. Hales]] for their paper "A proof of the [[Kepler conjecture]]," [[Annals of Mathematics]], 162:1065–1185, 2005.
==Winners (MAA Robbins Prize)== * 2017 :[[Robert Hough(mathematician)]] for his paper "Solution of the minimum modulus problem for covering systems", [[Annals of Mathematics]], 181: 361-382, 2015. * 2014 : [[Frederick V. Henle]] and [[James M. Henle]] for their paper "Squaring the plane”, [[The American Mathematical Monthly]], 115:3–12, 2008. * 2011 : [[Mike Paterson]], [[Yuval Peres]], [[Mikkel Thorup]], [[Peter Winkler]], and [[Uri Zwick]] for their papers [https://arxiv.org/abs/0710.2357 "Overhang”], [[The American Mathematical Monthly]], 116:19–44, 2009, and [https://arxiv.org/abs/0707.0093 "Maximum Overhang”], [[The American Mathematical Monthly]], 116:763–787 2009. * 2008 : [[Neil Sloane]] for "The on-line encyclopedia of integer sequences”,<ref>[http://oeis.org The on-line encyclopedia of integer sequences]</ref> [[Notices of the American Mathematical Society]], 50:912–915, 2003.
