{{pp-move-indef}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} The '''Fritzl case''' emerged in April 2008, when a woman named Elisabeth Fritzl (born 6 April 1966) told police in the town of [[Amstetten, Lower Austria|Amstetten]], Austria, that she had been held captive for 24 years by her father, Josef Fritzl (born 9 April 1935). Fritzl had [[physical assault|assaulted]], [[sexual abuse|sexually abused]], and [[rape]]d her numerous times during her imprisonment inside a concealed area in the basement of the family home.<ref name="Spiegel online"/><ref name="BBCcellar"/> The abuse by Elisabeth's father resulted in the birth of seven children:<ref name=daysindarkness/> three of them remained in captivity with their mother, one had died just days after birth, and the other three were brought up by Fritzl and his wife, Rosemarie, having been reported as [[Child abandonment|foundlings]].
==Case history== {{Wikinewshas|related articles| * [[n:Austrian man kept daughter prisoner in cellar for 24 years|Austrian man kept daughter prisoner in cellar for 24 years]] * [[n:Police: Austrian children kept in dungeon were in 'oppressive' conditions|Police: Austrian children kept in dungeon were in 'oppressive' conditions]] * [[n:Trial date scheduled for Austrian man who kept his daughter in a dungeon for 24 years|Trial date scheduled for Austrian man who kept his daughter in a dungeon for 24 years]] * [[n:Austrian man who imprisoned daughter pleads guilty at start of trial|Austrian man who imprisoned daughter pleads guilty at start of trial]] }} Josef Fritzl was born on 9 April 1935, in [[Amstetten, Lower Austria|Amstetten]], Austria. In 1956, at age 21, he married 17-year-old Rosemarie, with whom he had two sons and five daughters, including Elisabeth, who was born in 1966. Fritzl reportedly began abusing Elisabeth in 1977 when she was 11.<ref>{{cite news |author= Susan Donaldson James |title= Elisabeth Fritzl’s Trauma Like ‘Walking Dead’ |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Health/Story?id=4768253&page=1 |work= |publisher= abcNEWS |id= |pages= 1–4 |date= 2 May 2008 |accessdate= 2 June 2009 |quote= }}</ref>
After completing [[compulsory education]] at age 15, Elisabeth started a course to become a waitress. In January 1983, she ran away from home and went into hiding in [[Vienna]] with a friend from work. She was found by police within three weeks and returned to her parents. She rejoined her waitress course, finished it in mid-1984, and was offered a job in nearby [[Linz]].
===Captivity=== On 28 August 1984, after Elisabeth turned 18, Fritzl lured her into the basement of the family home, saying he needed help carrying a door. This was the last piece needed to seal what would turn out to be the chamber where Elisabeth was held captive.<ref name="autogenerated2008" /> After Elisabeth held the door in place while Fritzl fitted it into the frame, he held an [[diethyl ether|ether]]-soaked towel on his daughter's face until she was unconscious, then threw her into the chamber.<ref name="autogenerated2008">{{Cite book |title=Monster |first=Allan |last=Hall |location=London |publisher=Penguin |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-14-103970-1}}</ref>
After Elisabeth's disappearance, Rosemarie filed a [[missing person]]s report. Almost a month later, Fritzl handed over a letter to the police, the first of several that he had forced Elisabeth to write while in captivity. The letter, postmarked [[Braunau am Inn|Braunau]], stated that Elisabeth was tired of living with her family and was staying with a friend; she warned her parents not to look for her or she would leave the country. Fritzl told police that she had most likely joined a religious [[cult]].<ref name=daysindarkness>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/0,1518,551660,00.html|title=The Amstetten Horror House: 8,516 Days in Darkness|publisher=[[Spiegel Online]]|date=6 May 2008|accessdate=6 May 2008}}</ref>
Over the next 24 years, Fritzl visited Elisabeth in the hidden chamber almost every day, or a minimum of three times a week, bringing food and other supplies. After his arrest, he admitted that he repeatedly [[rape]]d her. Elisabeth gave birth to seven children during her captivity.<ref name="daysindarkness" /> One child died shortly after birth, and three—Lisa, Monika, and Alexander—were removed from the cellar as infants to live with Fritzl and his wife, who were approved by local [[social services]] authorities as their [[foster care|foster parents]]. Officials said that Fritzl "very plausibly" explained how three of his infant grandchildren had appeared on his doorstep. The family received regular visits from social workers, who saw and heard nothing to arouse their suspicions.<ref name="BBCProfileJFriztl" />
Following the fourth child's birth in 1994, Fritzl allowed the enlargement of the prison, from {{convert|35|to|55|m2|sqft|abbr=on}}, putting Elisabeth and her children to work for years digging out soil with their bare hands. The captives had a television, radio, and video cassette player. Food could be stored in a refrigerator and cooked or heated on [[hot plate]]s.<ref name="DailyMail1">{{cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/cellar-monster-josef-fritzl-faces-3000-rape-charges-in-december-trial-6849449.html |title=Cellar monster Josef Fritzl faces 3,000 rape charges in December trial|publisher=[[London Evening Standard]]|date=25 August 2008|accessdate=27 April 2018 | location=London}}</ref> Elisabeth taught the children to read and write. At times, Fritzl shut off their lights or refused to deliver food for days at a time to punish them.<ref name="Time2008-10-23" />
Fritzl told Elisabeth and the three children who remained (Kerstin, Stefan, and Felix) that they would be gassed if they tried to escape. Investigators concluded that this was just an empty threat to frighten the captives; there was no gas supply to the basement.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/austria/1960151/Josef-Fritzlandrsquos-threats-to-gas-family-were-a-bluff.html|title= Josef Fritzl's threats to gas family were a bluff|publisher=Daily Telegraph|first=Adreas|last=Sam|date=16 May 2008|accessdate=16 May 2008 | location=London}}</ref> He stated after his arrest that he told them that they would receive an electric shock and die if they meddled with the cellar door.<ref name=GuardianQuotes/>
According to Fritzl's sister-in-law Christine, he went into the basement every morning at 09:00, ostensibly to draw plans for machines which he sold to firms. Often he stayed there for the night and did not allow his wife to bring him coffee. A tenant who rented a ground-floor room in the house for twelve years claimed to hear noises from the basement, which Fritzl explained were from the "faulty pipes" or the gas heating system.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7377344.stm|title='Second man' at Austrian cellar|publisher=BBC News|date=1 May 2008|accessdate=6 May 2008}}</ref>
===Discovery=== On 19 April 2008, Fritzl agreed to seek medical attention after Kerstin, the eldest daughter, fell unconscious. Elisabeth helped him carry Kerstin out of the chamber and saw the outside world for the first time in 24 years. Fritzl forced her to return to the chamber, where she remained for a final week.<ref name=daysindarkness/> Kerstin was taken by [[ambulance]] to a local hospital, the Landesklinikum Amstetten, and was admitted in serious condition with life-threatening [[kidney failure]]. Fritzl later arrived at the hospital claiming to have found a note written by Kerstin's mother. He discussed Kerstin's condition and the note with Dr. Albert Reiter.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/7373233.stm|title=Doctor found note from victim|publisher=BBC News|date=29 April 2008|accessdate=19 May 2008}}</ref>
Medical staff found aspects of Fritzl's story puzzling and alerted the police on 21 April, who then broadcast an appeal via public media for the missing mother to come forward and provide additional information about Kerstin's medical history.<ref name="Telepgraph2">{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/joseffritzl/2101452/Josef-Fritzl-daughter-Kerstin-wakes-from-coma-and-is-reunited-with-her-family.html | title=Fritzl girl wakes from coma and is reunited with her family | publisher=The Daily Telgraph | date=9 June 2008 | accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="AustriaSaysManLockedUpDaughter">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/29/world/europe/29austria.html|title=Austria Says Man Locked Up Daughter|first=Mark|last=Landler|authorlink=Mark Landler|date=28 April 2008|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|accessdate=29 April 2008}}</ref> The police reopened the case file on Elisabeth's disappearance. Fritzl repeated his story about Elisabeth being in a cult, and presented what he claimed was the "most recent letter" from her, dated January 2008, posted from the town of [[Kematen an der Krems|Kematen]].<ref name="daysindarkness" /> The police contacted Manfred Wohlfahrt, a church officer and expert on cults, who raised doubts about the existence of the group Fritzl described. He noted that Elisabeth's letters seemed dictated and oddly written.
Elisabeth pleaded with Fritzl to be taken to the hospital. On 26 April, he released her from the cellar along with her sons Stefan and Felix, bringing them upstairs. He and Elisabeth went to the hospital where Kerstin was being treated on 26 April 2008. Following a tip-off from Reiter that Josef and Elisabeth were at the hospital, the police detained them on the hospital grounds and took them to a police station for questioning.
Elisabeth did not provide police with more details until they promised her that she would never have to see her father again. Over the next two hours, she told the story of her 24 years in captivity. Elisabeth told the police that Fritzl raped her and forced her to watch [[pornography|pornographic]] videos, which he made her reenact with him in front of her children in order to humiliate her.<ref name=daysindarkness/> Shortly after midnight, police officers completed the interview. Fritzl, aged 73, was arrested on 26 April on suspicion of serious crimes against family members.<ref name="BBCtimeline">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7370208.stm|title=Timeline: Austrian cellar case|publisher=BBC News|date=19 March 2009}}</ref>
During the night of 27 April, Elisabeth, her children and her mother Rosemarie were taken into care. Police said Fritzl told investigators how to enter the basement chamber through a small hidden door, opened by a secret [[Remote keyless system|keyless entry code]]. Rosemarie had been unaware of what had been happening to Elisabeth.<!-- repetitious -- It is believed she assumed, due to the letters in her handwriting, that her daughter had run away from home to join a religious [[cult]].<ref name="AustriaSaysManLockedUpDaughter"/><ref>{{cite news|first=Matthew|last=Weaver|coauthors=Connolly, Kate|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/apr/28/austria.internationalcrime2?gusrc=rss&feed=networkfront|title=Austrian cellar case man admits abduction and incest|date=29 April 2008|accessdate=29 April 2008|publisher=guardian.co.uk | location=London}}</ref> -->
On 29 April, it was announced that [[DNA]] evidence confirmed Fritzl as the biological father of his daughter's children.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7373689.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=29 April 2008|accessdate=29 April 2008|title=DNA 'backs Austrian incest claim'}}</ref> His defense lawyer, Rudolf Mayer, said that although the DNA test proved [[incest]], evidence was still needed for the allegations of rape and enslavement.<ref>{{cite news|first=Nick|last=Allen|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1913953/Lawyer-Fritzl-denies-rape-and-abduction.html|title=Lawyer: Fritzl denies rape and abduction|publisher=telegraph.co.uk|date=29 April 2008|accessdate=29 April 2008 | location=London}}</ref> In their 1 May daily [[press conference]], Austrian police said that Fritzl had forced Elisabeth to write a letter the previous year indicating that he may have been planning to release her and the children. The letter said that she wanted to come home but "it's not possible yet".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/article.html?in_article_id=145605&in_page_id=34|title=Fritzl made daughter write 'fake' release letter|publisher=metro.co.uk|date=1 May 2008|accessdate=1 May 2008}}</ref> Police believe Fritzl was planning to pretend to have rescued his daughter from her fictitious cult.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/43127/How-Fritzl-planned-to-blame-years-of-torture-on-evil-sect|title=How Fritzl Planned To Blame Years Of Torture On Evil Sect|date=2 May 2008|accessdate=2 May 2008|publisher=Daily Express}}</ref> Police spokesman Franz Polzer said police planned to interview at least 100 people who had lived as tenants in the Fritzl apartment building in the previous 24 years.<ref name="CNN2">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/the-family-man-of-amstetten-double-life-of-a-pillar-of-austrian-society-820880.html|title=The Family Man of Amstetten: Double life of a pillar of Austrian society|publisher=The Independent|date=27 October 2011|accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref>
==Cell== The Fritzl property in Amstetten is a building dating from around 1890. A newer building was added after 1978 when Fritzl applied for a building permit for an "extension with basement". In 1983, building inspectors visited the site and verified that the new extension had been built according to the dimensions specified on the permit. Fritzl had illegally enlarged the room by excavating space for a much larger basement, concealed by walls. Around 1981 or 1982, according to his statement,<ref name="GuardianQuotes" /> Fritzl started to turn this hidden cellar into a [[prison cell]] and installed a washbasin, toilet, bed, hot plate, and refrigerator. In 1983, he added more space by creating a passageway to a pre-existing basement area under the old part of the property, of which only he knew.
The concealed cellar had a {{convert|5|m|yd|1|adj=mid|-long}} corridor, a storage area, and three small open cells, connected by narrow passageways; and a basic cooking area and bathroom facilities, followed by two sleeping areas, which were equipped with two beds each. It covered an area of approximately {{convert|55|m2|sqft|abbr=on}}. The cell had two access points: a hinged door that weighed 500 kg (1,100 lb) which is thought to have become unusable over the years because of its weight, and a metal door, reinforced with concrete and on steel rails that weighed 300 kg (650 lb) and measured {{convert|1|m|ft|1|abbr=on}} high and {{convert|60|cm|ft|0|abbr=on}} wide. It was located behind a shelf in Fritzl's basement workshop, protected by an electronic code entered using a remote control unit. In order to reach this door, five locking basement rooms had to be crossed. To get to the area where Elisabeth and her children were held, eight doors in total needed to be unlocked, of which two doors were additionally secured by electronic locking devices.<ref name="Spiegel online"/><ref name="BBCcellar">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7384182.stm|title=Cellar in abuse case described|publisher=BBC News|date=5 May 2008|accessdate=6 May 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7373172.stm|title= Inside Josef Fritzl's cellar dungeon|publisher=BBC News|date=30 April 2008|accessdate=10 May 2008}}</ref>
==Key events== The key events are as follows: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date !! Key event |- |1977|| Fritzl begins [[child molestation|sexually abusing]] his 11-year-old daughter Elisabeth.<ref name=TimelineAustriancellarcase>{{cite news|first=Matthew|last=Weaver|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/apr/28/austria.internationalcrime1|title=Timeline: Austrian cellar case|publisher=[[guardian.co.uk]]|accessdate=29 April 2008|date=28 April 2008 | location=London}}</ref> |- |1981–82|| Fritzl begins to turn the hidden cellar into a prison cell.<ref name="BBCProfileJFriztl" /> |- |style="white-space:nowrap;"|28 August 1984|| Fritzl lures 18-year-old Elisabeth into the basement and imprisons her.<ref name="BBCtimeline"/> |- |November 1986 ||Elisabeth has a miscarriage in the 10th week of pregnancy.<ref name="Elisabethgavebirthalone">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/joseffritzl/4999268/Josef-Fritzl-trial-Elisabeth-gave-birth-alone-and-afraid.html|title=Josef Fritzl trial: Elisabeth gave birth alone and afraid|first=Caroline|last=Gammell|date=16 March 2009|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]''}}</ref>
|- |August 1988|| Kerstin is born, and lives in the cellar until 2008.<ref name="Elisabethgavebirthalone"/> |- |February 1990 || Stefan is born. He also stays in the cellar until 2008.<ref name="Elisabethgavebirthalone"/> |- |August 1992 || Lisa is born. In May 1993, at 9 months old, she is discovered outside the family home in a cardboard box, allegedly left there by Elisabeth with a note asking for the child to be looked after.<ref name="Elisabethgavebirthalone"/><ref name="timelinefritzlcellarcase">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/16/josef-fritzl-cellar-case-timeline|title=Timeline: Fritzl cellar case|first=Helen|last=Pidd|date=18 March 2009|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''}}</ref> |- | 1993 || After repeated requests by Elisabeth, Fritzl allows the enlargement of the prison, putting Elisabeth and her children to work for years digging out soil with their hands. The prison was enlarged from 35 m² (380 sq ft) to 55 m² (600 sq ft).<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/may/06/austria.internationalcrime|title=Fritzl began plans for dungeon in 1978|first=Kate|last=Connolly|date=6 May 2008|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''}}</ref> |- | February 1994 || The fourth child, Monika, is born.<ref name="Elisabethgavebirthalone"/> |- | December 1994 || 10-month-old Monika is found in a stroller outside the entrance of the house. Shortly afterwards, Rosemarie receives a phone call, asking her to take care of the child. The caller sounds like Elisabeth, but it is assumed that Fritzl used a recording of her voice. Rosemarie reported the incident to the police, expressing astonishment that Elisabeth knew their new, unlisted phone number.<ref name=daysindarkness/> |- | April 1996 || Elisabeth gives birth to twin boys. One dies after less than 3 days and Fritzl removes and [[cremation|cremates]] the body. The surviving twin, Alexander, is taken upstairs at 15 months old and "discovered" in circumstances similar to those of his two sisters.<ref name="Elisabethgavebirthalone"/><ref name="firstfiveyears">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/19/josef-fritzl-austria|title=Josef Fritzl trial: 'She spent the first five years entirely alone. He hardly ever spoke to her'|first=Kate|last=Connolly|date=16 March 2009|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''}}</ref><ref name="timelinefritzlcellarcase"/> |- | December 2002 || Felix is born. According to a statement by Fritzl, he kept Felix in the cellar with Elisabeth and her two eldest children because his wife could not look after another child.<ref name=daysindarkness/> |- | 19 April 2008 || Fritzl arranges for critically ill 19-year-old Kerstin to be taken to a local hospital.<ref name=daysindarkness/> |- | 26 April 2008 || During the evening, Fritzl releases Elisabeth, Stefan, and Felix from the cellar and brings them upstairs, informing his wife that Elisabeth had decided to come home after a 24-year absence. Later that evening, after an anonymous tipoff during a visit to the hospital, Fritzl and Elisabeth are taken into police custody where she reveals her decades-long imprisonment during questioning.<ref name=daysindarkness/> |- | 19 March 2009 ||After a 4-day trial in the town of St. Pölten, just days before his 74th birthday, Fritzl pleads guilty to the charges of the [[negligent homicide|murder by negligence]] of his infant son (and grandson) Michael, as well as the decades of [[enslavement]], [[incest]], [[rape]], [[coercion]] and [[false imprisonment]] of his daughter Elisabeth, and is sentenced to [[life imprisonment]].<ref name="BBCProfileJFriztl" /> |}
== Josef Fritzl == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Mugshot of Josef Fritzl on the night of his arrest.jpg|thumb|Mugshot of Josef Fritzl on the night of his arrest.]] --> {{Infobox criminal | name = Josef Fritzl | image = | image_upright = | image_size = | alt = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1935|4|9}} | birth_place = [[Amstetten, Lower Austria|Amstetten]], [[Federal State of Austria|Austria]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Austrian | known_for = imprisoning and raping his daughter, Elisabeth | conviction = [[Negligent homicide|Murder by negligence]] and other charges | conviction_penalty = [[Life imprisonment]] | conviction_status = Incarcerated at [[Garsten Abbey]] | spouse = Rosemarie Fritzl | footnotes = }}
===Biography=== Josef Fritzl (now known as Mayrhoff) was born on 9 April 1935, in Amstetten to Josef Fritzl Sr and Maria Fritzl. He grew up as an [[only child]] raised solely by his working mother. His father had deserted the family when Fritzl was four, and never again came into contact with him. Fritzl Sr later fought as a soldier in the [[Wehrmacht]] during [[World War II]], and was killed in action in 1944. His name appears on a memorial plaque in Amstetten.<ref>''Secrets of the Cellar'': [[John Glatt]]</ref> In 1956, at the age of 21, he married Rosemarie, 17, with whom he had two sons and five daughters.
After completing his education at an [[Höhere Technische Lehranstalt|HTL Technical College]] with a qualification in electrical engineering, Fritzl obtained a job at [[Voestalpine]] in Linz. From 1969 until 1971, he obtained a job in a construction material firm in Amstetten. Later, he became a technical equipment salesman, travelling throughout Austria. He retired from active employment when he turned 60 in 1995, but continued some commercial activities thereafter. In addition to his apartment building in Amstetten, Fritzl rented out several other properties.<ref name="BBCProfileJFriztl">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7371959.stm|title=Profile: Josef Fritzl|date=19 March 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=6 May 2008}}</ref><ref name="Spiegel online">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/0,1518,551451-2,00.html|title=How Josef Fritzl Created his Regime of Terror|accessdate=6 May 2008|author1=Dahlkamp, Jürgen |author2=Kraske, Marion |author3=Von Mittelstaedt, Juliane |author4=Röbel, Sven |author5=Von Rohr,Mathieu |date=5 May 2008|publisher=[[Der Spiegel#Spiegel Online|Spiegel Online]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://noe.orf.at/stories/274341/|title=Wer ist Josef Fritzl?|publisher=[[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]]|date=29 April 2008|language=German|accessdate=6 May 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5g6TMNOu02XFDEmyr9rQRBGdPEt3AD90DO2AG0 |title=Josef Fritzl: a shrewd liar and an obsessive tyrant |author=Bradley S. Klapper |agency=Associated Press |date=2 May 2008 |accessdate=18 May 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516001846/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5g6TMNOu02XFDEmyr9rQRBGdPEt3AD90DO2AG0 |archivedate=16 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 1972, he purchased a guesthouse and an adjacent campsite at [[Mondsee (lake)|Lake Mondsee]]. He ran it, together with his wife, until 1996.
===Criminal history=== In 1967, Fritzl broke into the Linz home of a 24-year-old nurse while her husband was away and raped her while holding a knife to her throat, threatening to kill her if she screamed.<ref name="Nurse">{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/austria/1920887/Austria-Josef-Fritzl-could-face-murder-charges.html | title=Joseph Fritzl Could Face Murder Charges | publisher=The Daily Telegraph | accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref> According to an annual report for 1967 and a press release of the same year, he was also named as a suspect in a case of attempted rape of a 21-year-old woman, and was known for [[indecent exposure]]. Fritzl was arrested and served twelve months of an eighteen-month prison sentence.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/sex-slave-dungeon-i-knew-fritzl-had-raped-his-daughter-says-man-upstairs-6686436.html | location=London | work=The Evening Standard | title=Sex slave dungeon: I knew Fritzl had raped his daughter, says man upstairs | date=12 April 2012}}</ref> In accordance with Austrian law, his criminal record was expunged after fifteen years. As a result, more than 25 years later, when he applied to adopt and/or foster Elisabeth's children, the local social service authorities did not discover his criminal history.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7380969.stm|title= Police study old Fritzl sex case|publisher=BBC News|date=2 May 2008|accessdate=2 May 2008}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/justiz/der-fall-amstetten-wie-josef-fritzl-die-behoerden-taeuschte-a-551598.html|title=Der Fall Amstetten: Wie Josef Fritzl die Behörden täuschte|last=Mathieu|first=von Rohr|date=6 May 2008|website=SPIEGEL ONLINE|language=German|access-date=25 May 2016}}</ref>
===Self-portrayal and psychiatric assessment=== After his arrest, Fritzl claimed that his behavior toward his daughter did not constitute rape but was consensual. Mayer forwarded extracts from the minutes of his talks with his client to the Austrian weekly ''[[NEWS (Austrian magazine)|News]]'' for publication. According to these statements, Fritzl said that he "always knew during the whole 24 years that what I was doing was not right, that I must have been crazy to do such a thing, yet it became a normal occurrence to lead a second life in the basement of my house."
Regarding his treatment of the family he had with his wife, Fritzl stated, "I am not the beast the media make me to be". Regarding his treatment of Elisabeth and her children in the cellar, he explained that he brought flowers for Elisabeth and books and toys for the children into the "bunker", as he called it, and often watched videos with the children and ate meals with Elisabeth and the children. Fritzl decided to imprison Elisabeth after she "did not adhere to any rules any more" when she became a teenager. "That is why I had to do something; I had to create a place where I could keep Elisabeth, by force if necessary, away from the outside world." He suggested that the emphasis on discipline in the [[Nazi Germany|Nazi era]], during which he grew up, might have influenced his views about decency and good behavior. The chief editors of ''News'' magazine noted in their editorial that they expected Fritzl's statement to form the basis of the defence strategy of his lawyer. Critics said his statement may have been a ploy to prepare an [[insanity defence]].<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/world/fritzl-blames-nazis-and-speaks-of-mother-love/2008/05/09/1210131264654.html|first=Andreas|last=Sam|title = Fritzl blames Nazis and speaks of mother's love|work=The Age|date=10 May 2008|accessdate=10 May 2008|location=Melbourne}}</ref>
Reflecting on his childhood, Fritzl initially described his mother as "the best woman in the world" and "as strict as it was necessary".<ref name=GuardianQuotes>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/may/09/joseffritzl.austria1|title='The urge to taste forbidden fruit was too strong'|accessdate=12 May 2008|author=Elizabeth Stewart and agencies|date=9 May 2008|work=The Guardian|location=London}}</ref> Later, he expressed a negative opinion of his mother and claimed that "she used to beat me, hit me until I was lying in a pool of blood on the floor. It left me feeling totally humiliated and weak. My mother was a servant and she used to work hard all her life, I never had a kiss from her, I was never cuddled although I wanted it – I wanted her to be good to me." He also claimed that she called him "a [[Satan]], a criminal, a no-good", that he "had a horrible fear of her". In 1959, after Fritzl had married and bought his house, his mother moved in with them. Over time, their roles reversed, and his mother came to fear him. Eventually, he also admitted he had later locked his mother in the attic and bricked up her window after telling neighbors that she had died, and kept her locked up until her death in 1980. It is unknown how long Fritzl kept his mother locked up in his attic, but newspapers have speculated that it may have been up to 20 years.<ref>{{cite web|first=Angela |last=Balakrishnan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/oct/31/joseffritzl-austria |title=Josef Fritzl kept sick mother locked in attic, leaked papers reveal |publisher=The Guardian |date=31 October 2008 |accessdate=14 September 2012}}</ref><ref>Matthew Moore, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/3281656/Josef-Fritzl-admits-locking-mother-in-bricked-up-room-at-dungeon-house.html Josef Fritzl admits locking mother in bricked-up room at dungeon house], 29 October 2008, The Daily Telegraph.</ref>
In a report by [[forensic psychiatry|forensic psychiatrist]] Adelheid Kastner, Fritzl's mother is described as unpredictable and abusive. Fritzl referred to himself as an "alibi" child, meaning that his mother only gave birth to him to prove that she was not barren and could produce children. Fritzl claims that his [[pathology|pathological]] behavior is innate. He admits that he planned to lock his daughter up during his prison stint for the earlier rape conviction so that he could contain and express his "[[evil]] side". He said, "I was born to rape, and I held myself back for a relatively long time. I could have behaved a lot worse than locking up my daughter."<ref name="Time2008-10-23">Eben Harrell, [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1853330,00.html Austria's Sex-Slave Father Tells His Side of the Story], 23 October 2008, Time.</ref> The forensic psychiatrist diagnosed Fritzl as having a "severe [[mixed personality disorder|combined personality disorder]]" which included [[borderline personality disorder|borderline]], [[schizotypal personality disorder|schizotypal]], and [[schizoid personality disorder|schizoid]] personalities and a sexual disorder and recommended that Fritzl receive psychiatric care for the rest of his life.<ref name="Time2008-10-23" /><ref name="Connolly2009">{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/18/psychiatrist-analyses-josef-fritzl | title=Fritzl's troubled childhood analysed in court | publisher=The Guardian | date=18 March 2009 | accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref>
Recent reports have brought to light Fritzl's premeditated plan to lock his daughter up not for discipline but for his own gratification.<ref name="Time2008-10-23" /><ref name="Premeditated">{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/joseffritzl/4999175/Josef-Fritzl-trial-accused-hides-face-with-folder-in-court.html | title=Fritzl trial-accused-hides-face-with-folder-in-court | publisher=The Telegraph | work=The Telegraph | date=16 March 2009 | accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref>
===Prosecutor's investigation=== In keeping with the agreement that she would never have to see her father again, Elisabeth Fritzl gave videotaped testimony before Austrian prosecutors and investigators on 11 July 2008.<ref name="video">{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/fritzl-lets-the-mask-slip-as-his-daughter-tells-her-tragic-story-1647361.html | title=Fritzl lets the mask slip as his daughter tells her tragic story | publisher=The Independent | work=The Independent | date=22 October 2011 | accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref>
On 13 November 2008, authorities in Austria released an indictment against Josef Fritzl. He would stand trial for the murder of the infant Michael, who died shortly after birth,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/11/13/austria.fritzl/index.html|title=Austria incest suspect charged with murder|date=13 November 2008|website=CNN International Edition: Europe|publisher=CNN|access-date=25 May 2016}}</ref> and face between 10 years and [[life imprisonment]]. He was also charged with rape, [[incest]], kidnapping, false imprisonment and [[slavery]], which carry a maximum 20-year term.<ref name="BBCProfileJFriztl" />
==Trial of Josef Fritzl== The trial of Josef Fritzl commenced on 16 March 2009, in the city of [[Sankt Pölten]], presided over by Judge Andrea {{not a typo|Humer}}. [[File:Kriminalfall Amstetten Presse.JPG|thumb|left|Journalists during the Fritzl trial]]
On day one, Fritzl entered the courtroom attempting to hide his face from cameras behind a blue folder, which he was entitled to do under Austrian law. After opening comments, all journalists and spectators were asked to leave the courtroom, whereupon Fritzl lowered his binder. Fritzl pleaded guilty to all charges with the exception of murder and grievous assault by threatening to gas his captives if they disobeyed him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2009/03/2009316112944168657.html |title=Austria incest trial under way |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=16 March 2009 |accessdate=14 September 2012}}</ref>
In his opening remarks, Rudolf Mayer, the defending counsel, appealed to the jury to be objective and not be swayed by emotions. He insisted Fritzl was "not a monster", stating that Fritzl had brought a [[Christmas tree]] down to his captives in the cellar during the holiday season.<ref name="firstfiveyears"/>
Christiane Burkheiser, prosecuting her first case since being appointed Chief Prosecutor, pressed for [[life imprisonment]] in an institution for the criminally insane. She demonstrated for jurors the low height of the ceiling in the cellar dungeon by making a mark on the door to the courtroom at 1m 74 cm (5 ft 8.5in), and described the cellar as "damp and mouldy", passing around a box of musty objects taken from the cellar, the odour of which made jurors flinch.<ref name="Abused">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5917537.ece?token=null&offset=12&page=2|title=Josef Fritzl claims he was abused as a child|publisher=Times Online|date=16 March 2009|accessdate=17 March 2009 | location=London | first1=Jenny | last1=Booth | first2=Roger | last2=Boyes}}</ref><ref name="Prosecutor">{{cite web | url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/world/josef-fritzl-the-absolute-ruler-of-his-underground-concrete-hell-1-1030194 | title=Josef Fritzl: The absolute ruler of his underground concrete hell | publisher=The Scotsman | work=The Scotsman | date=17 March 2009 | accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref>
On the first day of testimony, jurors watched 11 hours of testimony recorded by Elisabeth in sessions with police and psychologists in July 2008. The tape is said to have been so "harrowing" that the eight jurors did not watch more than two hours at a time. Four replacement jurors were on standby to replace any of the regular jurors in case they could not bear to hear any more of the evidence.<ref name="trialputsspotlight">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/14/fritzl-austria-case|title=Fritzl trial puts spotlight on Austria but grisly case leaves long shadow|last=Connolly|first=Kate|date=14 March 2009|publisher=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=16 March 2009}}</ref>
Besides the video testimony, Elisabeth's older brother Harald testified, as did a doctor specialising in [[neonatal medicine]] and the court psychiatrist.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5928188.ece|title=Josef Fritzl on suicide watch as "avenging angel" daughter gives damning testimony|publisher=Times Online|date=18 March 2009|accessdate=22 March 2009 | location=London |first=Roger |last=Boyes}}</ref> Josef's wife, Rosemarie, and Elisabeth's children refused to testify.<ref name="Abused"/>
On 18 March 2009, Elisabeth Fritzl attended the second day of the criminal trial against her father Josef, in preparation for a book she is to write about her ordeal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/world/article.html?Elisabeth_Fritzl_was_in_court_to_watch_father&in_article_id=586685&in_page_id=64|title=Elisabeth Fritzl 'was in court to watch father'|date=18 March 2009|publisher=Metro |accessdate=19 March 2009}}</ref> She does not plan to see her father again.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/austria/1946950/Elisabeth-Fritzl-I-never-want-to-see-my-father-Josef-again.html|title=Elisabeth Fritzl: I never want to see my father Josef again|date=11 May 2008|publisher=Daily Telegraph |accessdate=19 March 2009}}</ref> Fritzl's attorney, Rudolf Mayer, confirmed that she had been in the visitors' gallery in disguise at the time her video testimony was aired. "Josef Fritzl recognised that Elisabeth was in court and, from this point on, you could see Josef Fritzl going pale and he broke down", Mayer said. "It was a meeting of eyes that changed his mind."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5937416.ece|title="Fritzl met Elisabeth's eyes — that changed his mind," says lawyer|publisher=Times Online|date=19 March 2009|accessdate=22 March 2009 | location=London | first=Philippe | last=Naughton}}</ref> The next day, Fritzl began the proceedings by approaching the judge and changing his pleas to guilty on all charges.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7949967.stm|title=Josef Fritzl admits all charges |date=18 March 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=19 March 2009}}</ref>
On 19 March 2009, Fritzl was sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole for 15 years.<ref name="BBCProfileJFriztl" /> He said that he accepted the sentence and would not appeal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5941516.ece|title=Jozef Fritzl: no plans for investigation into police and social service failings|publisher=Times Online|date=20 March 2009|accessdate=22 March 2009 | location=London | first=Roger | last=Boyes}}</ref> Fritzl is currently serving out his sentence in [[Garsten Abbey]], a former monastery in [[Upper Austria]] that has been converted into a prison.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100805050949/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5950413.ece | work=The Times of London | title=Fritzl prison has gym, choir and tennis classes | date=22 March 2009 | accessdate=23 September 2010 | first=Bojan | last=Pancevski}}</ref>
===Government response=== Describing the "abominable events" as linked to one individual case, [[Chancellor of Austria]] [[Alfred Gusenbauer]] said he planned to launch an image campaign to restore the country's reputation abroad.<ref name="bbctrial">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7375904.stm|title=Cellar father refuses to explain|publisher=BBC News|date=30 April 2008|accessdate=30 April 2008}}</ref>
==Aftermath== Judge Andrea {{not a typo|Humer}}, who presided over the trial, stated medical experts reported Elisabeth and her children were in "relatively good health".
After being taken into care, Elisabeth, all six of her surviving children and her mother were housed in a local clinic where they were shielded from the outside environment and received medical and psychological treatment. Members of the Fritzl family were offered new identities but it was emphasized that it was their choice to make.<ref name="CNN2"/>
Berthold Kepplinger, head of the clinic where Elisabeth and her children were being treated, said that Elisabeth and the three children held captive in the cellar required further therapy to help them adjust to the light after years in semi-darkness. They also needed treatment to help them cope with all the extra space that they now had in which to move about.<ref name=IndSupport>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/europe/amstetten-cellar-victims-thank-town-for-support-828304.html|title=Amstetten cellar victims thank town for support|publisher=The Independent|first=Alan|last=Hall|date=15 May 2008|accessdate=15 May 2008 | location=London}}</ref>
In May 2008, a handmade poster created by Elisabeth, her children and her mother at the therapy facility was displayed in the Amstetten town centre. The message thanked local people for their support. "We, the whole family, would like to take the opportunity to thank all of you for sympathy at our fate", they wrote in their message. "Your compassion is helping us greatly to overcome these difficult times, and it shows us there also are good and honest people here who really care for us. We hope that soon there will be a time where we can find our way back into a normal life."<ref name=IndSupport/>
Kerstin was reunited with her family on 8 June 2008, when she was awakened from her [[induced coma|artificially induced coma]]. Doctors said that she would make a full recovery.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7447975.stm|title=Cellar incest girl 'will recover'|publisher=BBC News|date=11 June 2008|accessdate=12 June 2008}}</ref>
It was revealed that Elisabeth and her children were more [[psychological trauma|traumatized]] than previously thought. During captivity, Kerstin tore out her hair in clumps, and was reported to have shredded her dresses before stuffing them in the toilet. Stefan could not walk properly, because of his height of {{height|m=1.73|precision=0}}, which had forced him to stoop in the {{convert|1.68|m|ftin|adj=mid|-high}} cellar. It has also been revealed that normal everyday occurrences, such as the dimming of lights or the closing of doors, plunge Kerstin and Stefan into anxiety and [[panic attack]]s. The other three of Elisabeth's children who were raised by their father are being treated for anger and resentment at the events.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/fritzls-victims-face-life-in-care-20080820-3yvt.html?page=-1|title=Fritzl's victims face life in care|publisher=The Age|date=21 August 2008|accessdate=9 September 2008 | location=Melbourne | first1=Allan | last1=Hall}}</ref>
In late July 2008, it emerged that Elisabeth ordered her mother Rosemarie out of the villa they had been sharing in a secret location set up for them by a [[psychiatric clinic]]. Elisabeth was upset about Rosemarie's passiveness during Elisabeth's upbringing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/fritzl-family-split-elisabeth-kicks-320511|title=Fritzl family split: Elisabeth kicks Rosemarie out of safe house|last=Mulchrone|first=Patrick|date=25 July 2008|publisher=The Mirror|access-date=30 October 2015}}</ref>
Lawyer Christoph Herbst, who represents Elisabeth and her family, said, "Fortunately, everything is going very well"; they spend their time answering hundreds of letters from all over the world. Felix, Kerstin, and Stefan, brought up underground with their mother, have learned to swim. All of Elisabeth's children attended a four-day summer camp organised by firefighters, with 4,000 other young campers, in August 2008. The children, along with their mother, also have made day trips, including swimming outings, on which care was taken to keep them out of reach of the paparazzi and to protect their privacy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/austrian-abuse-victims-slowly-exposed-20080711-3dw8.html|title=Austrian abuse victims slowly exposed|date=12 July 2008|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|publisher=Associated Press|access-date=25 May 2016}}</ref>
In March 2009, Elisabeth and her children were forced to move out of the family's hide-away home and returned to the psychiatric clinic where medical staff had started trying to heal the family and unite the "upstairs" and "downstairs" siblings during the previous year. Elisabeth was reported to be distraught and close to a breakdown after a British [[paparazzi|paparazzo]] had burst into her kitchen and started taking photographs.<ref name="trialputsspotlight" />
After the trial, Elisabeth and her six children were moved to an unnamed village in northern Austria, where they are living in a fortress-like house.<ref>{{cite news|first=Roger|last=Boyes |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5947460.ece|title=Elisabeth Fritzl seeks refuge with children in a fortress|publisher=Times Online|date=21 March 2009|accessdate=22 March 2009 | location=London}}</ref> All of the children require ongoing therapy. Factors that traumatised the "upstairs" children include learning that Josef had lied to them about their mother abandoning them, the abuse they had received from him during their childhood, and finding out that their siblings had been imprisoned in the cellar. The "downstairs" children receive therapy due to their deprivation from normal development, the lack of fresh air and sunshine while living confined in the basement, and the abuse that they and their mother had received from Josef when he visited them in the basement. All of the children might have genetic problems common to children born of an incestuous relationship.<ref name="Children">{{cite news|first=Roger|last=Boyes |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5941388.ece|title=Josef Fitzl's upstairs, downstairs families united for a new life in the open|publisher=Times Online|date=20 March 2009|accessdate=22 March 2009 | location=London}}</ref> Elisabeth was said to be estranged from her mother, Rosemarie, who accepted Josef's story about Elisabeth joining a cult and did not pursue the matter further, but Elisabeth allows her three children who grew up in Josef and Rosemarie's house to visit their grandmother regularly. Rosemarie lives alone in a small apartment.<ref name="Children" />
An article in March 2010 in ''[[The Independent]]'' stated that Elisabeth and her children recovered remarkably well, given the difficult lives they endured for so long.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/whatever-became-of-elisabeth-fritzl-1924645.html | work=The Independent | title=Whatever became of Elisabeth Fritzl? | date=21 April 2010 | accessdate=29 July 2011 }}</ref> According to Josef's sister-in-law, Christine, Elisabeth enjoys spending her time shopping, taking frequent showers, and driving. She has passed her driving test without difficulty. Her relationship with Thomas, one of her bodyguards, was reported to be ongoing, with him becoming a big-brother figure to her children. All of Elisabeth's children have developed normal sibling relationships with each other, and after having trouble dealing with the traumatic events, the three "upstairs" children slowly began recognising Elisabeth as their mother. The children enjoy being outdoors, playing video games, and spending time with their mother and grandmother. Despite their strained relationship, Elisabeth and her mother Rosemarie started visiting each other more, and Elisabeth has reportedly forgiven her mother for believing her father's story.
On 28 June 2013, workers began filling the basement of the Fritzl home with concrete. Estate liquidator Walter Anzboeck stated that the construction would cost [[Euro|€]]100,000 and would take a week to complete. The house was to be sold on the open market. While most neighbours approved of the proposal, some preferred that the property be demolished due to its sordid history.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22989884 | title=Josef Fritzl's cellar in Austria concreted in | publisher=BBC | date=20 June 2013 | accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref> Asylum seekers were offered the house to live in.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/607253/Josef-Fritzl-s-House-of-Horror-to-be-offered-to-ASYLUM-SEEKERS | title=Josef Fritzl's 'House of Horror' to be offered to ASYLUM SEEKERS - because no one wants it | publisher=Daily Express | work=Daily Express | date=23 September 2015 | accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref> The house was sold for €160,000 in December 2016, and will be turned into apartments.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/europe/house-where-josef-fritzl-held-daughter-captive-is-sold-1.2895060|title=House where Josef Fritzl held daughter captive is sold |date=6 December 2016}}</ref>
In May 2017, Josef Fritzl changed his name to Josef Mayrhoff.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://m.heute.at/oesterreich/niederoesterreich/story/50994291 | title= Josef Fritzl (82) heißt jetzt mit Nachnamen Mayrhoff | publisher=Heutectic | work=Heute | date=12 May 2017 | accessdate=13 June 2017|trans-title=Josef Fritzl (82) is now named by the surname Mayrhoff|language=German}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Greek economic crisis}}
A [[referendum]] to decide whether or not [[Greece]] was to accept the conditions under which the [[European Union]] (EU), the [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) and the [[European Central Bank]] (ECB) would allow a 50% [[Haircut (finance)|haircut]] of Greek debt owed to private creditors was planned to be held in 2011.<ref name="Skai Papandreou">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/184900/dimopsifisma-kai-psifo-ebistosunis-zitise-o-prothupourgos-/ |title=Ρίσκα και αβεβαιότητες από την πολιτική "βόμβα" για δημοψήφισμα |trans-title=Risks and uncertainties by the political "bomb" for a referendum |publisher=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref> However, Prime Minister [[George Papandreou]] decided to cancel the referendum on 3 November,<ref>{{cite web|title=Hoping Greece Scraps Referendum, Dow Leaps 208|url=http://www.foxbusiness.com/investing/2011/11/03/hoping-referendum-is-scrapped-dow-leaps-200/|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=3 November 2011}}</ref> if the opposition parties vote in favour of the EU deal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Papandreou scraps Greek referendum as open warfare erupts in his party |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/03/papandreou-scraps-greek-referendum-euro |publisher=Guardian|accessdate=4 November 2011|location=London|first1=Helena|last1=Smith|first2=David|last2=Gow|date=3 November 2011}}</ref> The proposed referendum was later cancelled.
==Background== On 31 October 2011,<ref name="Euronews Referendum">{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/10/31/papandreou-calls-referendum-on-eu-deal-/ |title=Papandreou calls referendum on EU deal |publisher=[[Euronews]] |accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="BBC Referendum">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-15526719 |title=Greece debt crisis: Referendum promised on EU deal |publisher=[[BBC]] |accessdate=31 October 2011 |date=1 November 2011}}</ref> Prime Minister [[George Papandreou]] announced the referendum saying that: "We need wide consensus (for the aid programme). We are part of the eurozone [which means] many rights and many obligations. We will live up to our obligations."<ref name="date">{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-11/03/c_131226777.htm |title=Greek referendum possibly held on Dec. 4: Greek PM |work=Xinhuanet |accessdate=3 November 2011 |date=3 November 2011}}</ref>
Constitutional issues have arisen with regards to such a referendum, as Article 44 of the [[constitution of Greece]] specifies that referenda on critical national matters and social bills are permitted while referenda on fiscal bills are not.<ref name="Skai Syntagma">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/184903/ti-vlepei-to-sudagma-sto-arthro-44-gia-to-dimopsifisma-/ |title=Τι προβλέπει το Σύνταγμα στο άρθρο 44 για το δημοψήφισμα |trans-title=What the Article 44 of the Constitution provides for referenda |publisher=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref> This was to be Greece's first referendum not having to do with a change in the form of government,<ref name="Agelioforos Dimopsifismata">{{cite web |url=http://www.agelioforos.gr/default.asp?pid=7&ct=1&artid=116784 |title=Τα 7 δημοψήφισμα του νεοελληνικού κράτους |trans-title=The 7 referenda of the modern Greek state |work=Agelioforos |accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref> and the first referendum [[Greek republic referendum, 1974|since 1974]].<ref name="Agelioforos Dimopsifismata" />
==Date== Papandreou suggested the referendum would be held on 4 December.<ref name="date"/> However, [[Minister for Finance (Greece)|Finance Minister]] [[Evangelos Venizelos]] specified that the referendum would take place in 2012, after the plans for the haircut had been finalised.<ref name="Skai Venizelos">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/184902/eu-venizelos-apo-to-neo-etos-to-dimopsifisma-/ |title=Ευ. Βενιζέλος: Από το νέο έτος το δημοψήφισμα |trans-title=Evangelos Venizelos: Referendum to take place after the new year |publisher=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref> Other sources put the date of the referendum to December 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url= http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/3df63cc6-056d-11e1-8eaa-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1caMRwukq|title=Greek referendum likely to sidestep bail-out issue |date=2 November 2011|work=Financial Times |accessdate=2 November 2011}}</ref> According to [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] the referendum would have taken place on 4 or 5 December 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-11-02/greek-referendum-will-determine-nation-s-future-in-the-euro-sarkozy-says.html|title=Sarkozy: Referendum Will Decide Greece’s Future |date=2 November 2011|publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=2 November 2011|first=Helene|last=Fouquet}}</ref>
==Opinion polls== Polls in Greece suggested that up to 60% of Greeks were against the deal reached with the EU over Greek debt on 27 October 2011,<ref name="Euronews Referendum" /><ref name="BBC Referendum" /> however a survey in September 2011 showed that 63% of Greeks viewed the [[euro]] as something positive.<ref name="Public Issue Evro">{{cite web |url=http://www.publicissue.gr/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/eurosurvey-09-2011.pdf |title=Οι Έλληνες, το Ευρώ και η Δραχμή Νο. 2 |trans-title=The Greeks, the Euro and the Drachma No. 2 |publisher=Public Issue ([[Kathimerini]]) |accessdate=2 November 2011}}</ref> The same survey showed that 66% of Greeks viewed the return to the [[drachma]] as something negative.<ref name="Public Issue Evro" />
==Response== ===Domestic=== The initial response of the [[List of political parties in Greece|Greek political parties]] was negative.<ref name="Enet Omovrontia">{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=322397 |title=Ομοβροντία από την αντιπολίτευση που ζητάει εκλογές |trans-title=Opposition bursts, demanding elections |work=[[Eleftherotypia]] |accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref> [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]] leader [[Antonis Samaras]] described it as an "indirect national schism",<ref name="Enet Omovrontia" /> while most opposition parties demanded elections<ref name="Enet Omovrontia" /><ref name="Ethnos KKE">{{cite web |url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22767&subid=2&pubid=63507374 |title=ΚΚΕ: Εκλογές τώρα |trans-title=Communist Party of Greece: Elections now |publisher=Ethnos |accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="Ethnos ND">{{cite web |url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22767&subid=2&pubid=63507382 |title=ΝΔ: Ο Παπανδρέου πατάει γκάζι για το γκρεμό |trans-title=New Democracy: Papandreou is heading full speed ahead for the cliff |work=Ethnos |accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="Ethnos DA">{{cite web |url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22767&subid=2&pubid=63507380 |title=Δημοκρατική Αριστερά: Ας προχωρήσει η χώρα σε πρόωρες εκλογές |trans-title=Democratic Left: Let the country head for elections |work=Ethnos |accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref> and condemned the government for what they perceived to be a maneuvre to avoid early elections.<ref name="Enet Omovrontia" /> [[Konstantinos Mitsotakis]], Prime Minister of Greece between 1990 and 1993, described the move to hold a referendum as utterly irrational and irresponsible.<ref name="Neoi Fakeloi Mitsotakis">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/player/TV/?MMID=220465 |title=Νέοι Φάκελοι 31/10/2011 |trans-title=New Folders 31/10/2011 |publisher=New Folders ([[Skai TV]]) |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> The Greek media also adopted a negative stance, with many calling it a coercive move.<ref name="Skai Mparouti">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/opinions/article/184916/helladastomparmpouti/ |title=Η Ελλάδα στο μπαρμπούτι |trans-title=Greece on "gunpowder" |publisher=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=1 November 2011 |quote=Με το εκβιαστικό, και εξ ορισμού σχηματικό δίλημμα, που θέτει η κυβέρνηση, όπως και αν αυτό διατυπωθεί, επιχειρεί να πετάξει το μπαλάκι στον λαό• “υπερήφανε ελληνικέ λαέ είτε ψηφίζεις 'ναι' και αποδέχεσαι έτσι αδιαμαρτύρητα το μείγμα των όποιων πολιτικών μας, είτε ψηφίζεις 'όχι', απορρίπτεις τη συμφωνία με τα πλεονεκτήματά της ("κούρεμα" του χρέους, χαμηλότερα επιτόκια, δανειακή στήριξη ύψους 100 δισ. ευρώ) και τότε φταις εσύ και όχι το πολιτικό προσωπικό για τα επιγενόμενα. ["With the coercive, by definition, delemma that the government sets, however this may be worded, it is attempting to throw the ball on the side of the people; 'proud Greek people you either vote 'yes' and thus accept this government and its politicians without further protests, or you vote 'no' and you turn down the agreement (of 27 October) with the benefits it brings ("haircut" on the debt, lower interest rates, a loan of 100 billion euro) and then its your fault, and not the fault of the country's ruling politicians."] }}</ref><ref name="Enet Vofatai">{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=322416 |title=Φοβάται τις κάλπες και πετάει το μπαλάκι με δημοψήφισμα |trans-title=He's afraid of elections and he's "throwing the ball" with the referendum |work=[[Eleftherotypia]] |accessdate=1 November 2011 |quote=Επί της ουσίας, ο κ. Παπανδρέου ρίχνει το μπαλάκι στο λαό για μια μεγάλη και κρίσιμη απόφαση για το μέλλον της χώρας και βάζει με το δημοψήφισμα εκβιαστικά το δίλημμα «ή ψηφίζετε ναι, ή η χώρα πτωχεύει». ["Basically, Mr. Papandreou is throwing the ball to the people for a very big and crucial decision for the future of the country and through the referendum puts forth the coercive delemma of 'you either vote yes, or the country is going bust'."] }}</ref>
Following the announcement of the referendum on 31 October 2011, 1 November saw the resignation of one MP from the ruling party,<ref name="Enet Milena">{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=322623 |title=Φυλλορροεί το ΠΑΣΟΚ, ανεξαρτητοποιήθηκε και η Μιλένα |trans-title=Defoliation of PASOK, Milena becomes independent |work=[[Eleftherotypia]] |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> lowering Papandreou's government majority to 152 seats<ref name="Enet Milena" /> in the 300-seat [[Hellenic Parliament]]. An additional six members of Papandreou's [[Panhellenic Socialist Movement]] have demanded early elections.<ref name="Enet Saki">{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=322611 |title=Το ΠΑΣΟΚ είναι πλέον άδειο σακί |trans-title=PASOK is now an empty sack |work=[[Eleftherotypia]] |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref>
In the early hours of 2 November 2011, George Papandreou and his cabinet decided to speed up the referendum process,<ref name="Skai Epispeusi">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/185021/g-papandreou-tin-paraskeui-krinodai-ola-se-thesmiko-epipedo/ |title=Επίσπευση του δημοψηφίσματος αποφάσισε το υπουργικό |trans-title=Cabinet meetings decided to speed up referendum |publisher=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=2 November 2011}}</ref> and attacked the Greek media by calling them bankrupt and accusing them of having "gone mad" over the referendum.<ref name="Skai Epispeusi" /><ref name="Enet Lysaksan">{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.politikh&id=322687 |title=Λύσσαξε με τα "χρεωμένα ΜΜΕ", δίνει εξηγήσεις σε Ευρωπαίους και ΔΝΤ |trans-title=He went mad over the "bankrupt media", he is to give explanations to Europe and the IMF |work=[[Eleftherotypia]] |accessdate=2 November 2011}}</ref> Additionally the cabinet decided that a committee would be set up to decide the time when the referendum would take place and the question that people would be asked to vote on,<ref name="Skai Epispeusi" /> but only after the basic characteristics of the new memorandum with the Troika had been decided.<ref name="Skai Epispeusi" /> During that cabinet meeting, a number of ministers expressed concerns over the referendum.<ref name="Skai Epispeusi" /><ref name="To Vima ypourgiko">{{cite web |url=http://www.tovima.gr/politics/article/?aid=428059&h1=true |title=Επιμένει ο Πρωθυπουργός στο δημοψήφισμα - επιφυλάξεις υπουργών |trans-title=Prime Minister set on referendum - ministers express concerns |work=[[To Vima]] |accessdate=2 November 2011}}</ref>
;Financial markets The [[Athex]] stock market index fell amid concerns for instability,<ref>http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite2_1_04/11/2011_413373</ref> as well as global financial markets on concerns about EU stability and a possible Greek default on its debt.<ref name="economictimes.indiatimes.com">{{cite news|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/global-markets/greece-crisis-asian-shares-rally-over-3-on-hopes-greece-will-drop-referendum/articleshow/10604191.cms |deadurl=yes |work=The Times Of India |title=Greece Crisis: Asian shares rally over 3% on hopes Greece will drop referendum - The Economic Times |date=4 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111217093842/http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/global-markets/greece-crisis-asian-shares-rally-over-3-on-hopes-greece-will-drop-referendum/articleshow/10604191.cms |archivedate=December 17, 2011 }}</ref>
====Cancellation==== On 3 November, Papandreou reneged on his promise and announced that the referendum would not take place after all<ref name="Zero Hedge">{{cite web |url=http://www.zerohedge.com/news/greek-pm-tells-sky-news-he-has-scrapped-referendum-watch-sky-coverage-euro-crisis-live/ |title=Greek PM Tells Sky News He Has Scrapped Referendum: Watch Sky Coverage Of Euro Crisis Live |trans-title=Greek PM Tells Sky News He Has Scrapped Referendum: Watch Sky Coverage Of Euro Crisis Live |publisher=[[Sky News]] |accessdate=3 November 2011}}</ref> following the opposition of four ministers, including Finance Minister Evangelos Venizelos, who opposed the referendum amid calls for Papandreou to resign.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-15575198 | work=BBC News | title=Greek PM Papandreou 'ready to drop' bailout referendum | date=3 November 2011}}</ref> He said that the Greek presence in the eurozone "cannot depend on a referendum." Several MPs also resigned following the decision, with [[Nikos Salayannis]] said that: "The referendum is dead."<ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/11/201111310743878884.html</ref> In response, global financial markets rose.<ref name="economictimes.indiatimes.com"/> Following an emergency visit to [[Cannes]] for the [[2011 G-20 Cannes summit]], where Papandreou faced pressure to call off the referendum, New Democracy's spokesman Yiannis Michelakis said that "the comments made by Mr Papandreou, as well as those by [French President] Nicolas Sarkozy and [German Chancellor] [[Angela Merkel]], revealed that he suggested to them that in Greece there is a supposed questioning of whether Greece should remain in the eurozone and the European Union. It is clear that no such problem exists and that Mr Papandreou – through sudden and despicable misinformation – is trying to create it himself." Party chairperson Antonis Samaras also said that "the only problem that exists is Mr Papandreou remaining as prime minister,” said Michelakis. “He is dangerous and he has to go."<ref>http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_4080_03/11/2011_412992</ref>
The referendum was later canceled amidst domestic and foreign pressure. U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] said that though the G20 summit in Cannes sought to alleviate [[European sovereign debt]] concerns the "actions of Papandreou and the referendum issue got a lot of people nervous" and the EU proposal was "still the best recipe." Dutch Prime Minister [[Mark Rutte]] said the cancellation was a good decision amidst possible eurozone impatience with Greece. "It was a bizarre proposal. We think it’s of great importance to the eurozone that we prevent Greece from going bankrupt. But in the end, the euro is more important than Greece’s membership of the eurozone." Conversely former German Chancellor [[Gerhard Schroeder]] said that: "It’s no surprise Papandreou hardly had a chance to push through what was being demanded from him. The conservatives across Europe did very little to convince the Greek conservative opposition to stop acting irresponsibly."<ref>http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_05/11/2011_413386</ref>
====Vote of confidence==== During discussions for a [[vote of confidence]] held on 4 November 2011, Evangelos Venizelos, the Greek Minister of Finance, expressed his view that the decision on whether or not Greece should remain in the Eurozone is not something that should not be put to a referendum,<ref name="Skai Venizelos Dimopsifisma">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/185120/apostaseis-venizelou-apo-to-dimopsifisma-/ |title=Όχι» Ευάγγελου Βενιζέλου στο δημοψήφισμα |trans-title="No" by Evangelos Venizelos on the referendum |work=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=3 November 2011}}</ref> and called for a [[National unity government|government of national unity]].<ref name="Skai Venizelos Dimopsifisma" /> On 3 November, two other members of Papandreou's parliamentary group announced they would not give the government a vote of confidence.<ref name="Skai Kaili">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/185135/eua-kaili-den-tha-parasho-psifo-ebistosunis-/ |title=Εύα Καϊλή: Δεν θα παράσχω ψήφο εμπιστοσύνης |trans-title=Eva Kaili: I will not give a vote of confidence |work=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=3 November 2011}}</ref><ref name="Skai Katareusi">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/185126/anatarahi-sto-pasok-me-fodo-to-dimopsifisma-/ |title=Υπό κατάρρευση η Κυβέρνηση - Ραγδαίες εξελίξεις |trans-title=Government collapsing - Rapid developments |work=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=3 November 2011}}</ref> This lowered the ruling party's parliamentary group votes to 150, which was below the threshold for majority in the parliament (151 seats). Dimitris Lintzeris, a PASOK MP, said that "Papandreou is past"<ref name="Skai Lintzeris">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/185136/d-lidzeris-o-k-papandreou-sunista-parelthon/ |title=Δ. Λιντζέρης: Ο κ. Παπανδρέου συνιστά παρελθόν |trans-title=Dimitris Lintzeris: Mr. Papandreou is now past |work=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=3 November 2011}}</ref> and that "he continues to act carelessly and turns his failure into a coercive [referendum]".<ref name="Skai Lintzeris" />
Amid concerns that Greece could leave the eurozone dependent on the referendum result, Papandreou faced a vote of confidence in parliament on 4 November. He said that "I ask for the vote of confidence to avert the instability that would be caused if the country is dragged into elections. Now is the time for cooperation with good intentions and a feeling of national responsibility."<ref name="newgovt"/> Before the vote he pledged to step down saying that re-election was not important to him, thus avoiding infighting within PASOK;<ref name="talks"/> he also said that he would seek a coalition government for four months in order to pass the new EU debt agreement,<ref name="vote"/> though New Democracy rejected such a motion to join a coalition government.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-15604169 | work=BBC News | title=Greek PM Papandreou faces unity challenge over bailout | date=5 November 2011}}</ref> The motion passed with a vote of 153-145 in the 300 seat parliament, after PASOK's 152 MPs and [[Louka Katseli]], formerly a member of PASOK, supported the prime minister. She was then brought back into the party fold.<ref name="vote">http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/11/2011114212835975841.html</ref>
=====New government===== Following the vote of confidence, Papandreou met President [[Karolos Papoulias]] the next day to begin talks on forming a new coalition government. Papandreou also said that he would resign and allow another interim prime minister. Though New Democracy's Samaras demanded a [[snap election]], an interim coalition government could have possibly involved [[Popular Orthodox Rally]], [[Democratic Alliance (Greece)|Democratic Alliance]] and/or the [[Democratic Left (Greece)|Democratic Left]]. However, Democratic Alliance chairperson [[Dora Bakoyannis]] said that an interim government to pass the EU demanded austerity measures must include New Democracy to make the government viable.<ref name="newgovt"/> Bakoyiannis also added that "there is no point in us supporting Papandreou without Samaras, we don't have enough votes to make a difference anyway. We'll support a coalition and vote with them, without any demands of positions, if Papandreou and Samaras can work it out."<ref name="wsj"/> Though Samaras continued to demand a new election in saying that was the only option for "stabilisation of the country, to restore its image, and to emerge sooner from this nightmare,"<ref name="talks"/> he also added that an interim coalition government was a good idea in order to pass the bailout bill. Papandreou also said that: "My aim is to immediately create a government of co-operation. A lack of consensus would worry our European partners about our country's membership of the eurozone."<ref name="talks"/> He added that forming a coalition meant that he would "do whatever I can to help form a coalition government. The Oct. 26 decisions and obligations stemming from this are a condition for the country remaining in the euro." An anonymous member of PASOK suggested that Papandreou believed that Venizelos was the most appropriate person to head am interim coalition government as "Venizelos is the main negotiator in Europe, so there will be continuity, although New Democracy is fiercely against this proposal." Papandreou also hoped that a new government would be formed by 7 November, before eurozone finance ministers meet in Brussels to discuss the next scheduled bailout fund for Greece. However, according to PASOK, Papandreou would not resign until there was clarification on who would lead the coalition government and that he wanted a new government in the following week. LAOS also added that Samaras should reconsider his position as forming a coalition government has been "achieved with the departure of Papandreou from power."<ref name="wsj">{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20111105-701027.html | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=3rd UPDATE: Greek PM Begins Efforts To Form Coalition Government | date=5 November 2011}}</ref>
Finance Minister Evangelos Venizelos added that an interim administration would serve until the end of February, after which a new [[Next Greek legislative election|election]] would be called following the passage of the 8-billion-euro loan tranche.<ref name="newgovt">http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_05/11/2011_413394</ref> Papandreou added that "elections at this moment not only equal disaster but could not take place in the best interest of the people. There is one solution. To support the [EU bailout] deal with a multiparty approach, without elections, with a strong government" and that he sought to "immediately create a government of co-operation [because] a lack of consensus would worry our European partners about our country's membership of the eurozone."<ref name="talks">http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/11/201111591628572478.html</ref> An unnamed senior member of PASOK said that Papandreou would resign as soon as a new government is formed, possibly on the night of 6 November.<ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/11/201111613435173466.html</ref>
On 6 November, Papandreou and Samaras agreed to the formation of a new coalition government that would not be led by Papandreou<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57319394/greek-pm-to-step-down-for-new-government/ | work=CBS News | title=Greek PM to step down for new government}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2011/11/greece-deal-new-government-euro.html | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Greeks in deal on new government in bid to save bailout, euro}}</ref> following a meeting with Papoulias. Papoulias' office issues a statement that read the leader of the government would be decided by the leaders of the largest parties the following day, but it did no mention the tenure of the government. However, Papandreou said that "it is clear that this government will pass the baton but it will not pass it to a void - it will pass it to a new government, if we agree on it, and I hope this will happen soon. I'm not interested in being prime minister in the new government;" he also added that a new election should not be held before February or March until the bailout legislation is approved by parliament The announcement also followed a European Union deadline before a finance minister meeting on 7 November about the formation of a government and the enactment of a bailout agreement. Papoulias said that "an agreement was reached to form a new government to immediately lead the country to elections after ratifying the decisions taken by the European Council."<ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/11/2011116203756981236.html</ref>
[[Lucas Papademos]] was suggested as the possible leader of a new government.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/07/lucas-papademos-frontrunner-greek-pm | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Helena | last=Smith | title=Lucas Papademos emerges as frontrunner to be new Greek PM | date=7 November 2011}}</ref> He later agreed to be the interim prime minister until a future election.<ref name="english.aljazeera.net">http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/11/201111895652345832.html</ref> At the last minute there was controversy over Papademos amongst both PASOK and New Democracy and a joint announcement for the new PM was put off till 10 November. Samaras blamed PASOK for the delay saying that the [[constitution of Greece|constitution]] demanded that the ruling party had the prerogative to name a candidate for prime minister.
In what ''Al Jazeera'' called an "apparent farewell address" Papandreou said on television that: "We have agreed on someone who will unite us. I would like to wish every success to the new prime minister and of course the new government. I will stand by them and I will support them with all my strength."<ref name="english.aljazeera.net"/>
===International=== ;Supranational *{{flag|EU}}: President of the [[European Commission]] [[José Manuel Barroso]] and President of the [[European Council]] [[Herman Van Rompuy]] have issued a joint statement expressing their faith in the agreement of 27 October 2011 and that the country will honour the agreements it has made with the [[Eurozone]] and the world.<ref name="Skai Barozo">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/184979/tilefoniki-sunomilia-papandreou-barozo-robei/ |title=Τηλεφωνική συνομιλία Παπανδρέου με Μπαρόζο - Ρομπέι - Μέρκελ |trans-title=Papandreou telephone conversation with Barroso - Rompuy - Merkel |publisher=[[Skai TV]] |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> [[Joseph Daul]], chairman of the [[European People's Party (European Parliament group)|European People's Party]] in the [[European Parliament]], characterised the move to hold a referendum as "verging on a violation of the [[Maastricht Treaty]]."<ref name="Skai Daul">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/185078/z-dol-sta-oria-tis-paraviasis-tis-sunthikis-tis-ee-i-ellada/ |title=Ζ. |url=http://www.globalnews.ca/carney+commends+greek+referendum+touts+stability+in+canada/6442512418/story.html |title=Carney commends Greek referendum, touts stability in Canada |publisher=[[Global News]] |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> *{{FRA}}: [[President of the French Republic|President]] [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], said that he was 'appalled' by the move to bring the agreement to a
