The '''Papal Concert of Reconciliation''' was a historic musical event in the pontificate of [[Pope John Paul II]]. The concert took place in the Paul VI Auditorium at the [[Holy See|Vatican]] on January 17, 2004, in the presence of the Pontiff, Rav [[Elio Toaff]], the Emeritus [[Chief_Rabbi#Rome.2C_Italy|Chief Rabbi of Rome]], and Abdulawahab Hussein Gomaa, the Imam of the [[Mosque of Rome]],<ref name=LPC>{{cite web|last=London Philharmonic Choir|title=Papal Concert of Reconciliation|url=http://www.lpc.org.uk/tour_200401_rome.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120125830/http://www.lpc.org.uk/tour_200401_rome.html|archivedate=2008-11-20|df=}}</ref> and an audience of 7,000 invited guests.<ref name=Post-Gazette /> The concert also followed the first visit to the Vatican of Israel's two chief rabbis, both of whom attended the concert.<ref name="BBC News">{{cite news|last=Willey|first=David|title=Vatican concert unites faiths|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3406773.stm|accessdate=2012-08-21|newspaper=BBC News|date=2004-01-17}}</ref> It was conceived, created, and conducted by Sir [[Gilbert Levine]],<ref name="Pittsburgh Catholic" /> whose previous musical collaborations with the Pope, including the Papal Concert to Commemorate the [[Shoah]] in 1994 with the [[Royal Philharmonic Orchestra]]<ref name="NYTimes 1994">{{cite news|last=Tagliabue|first=John|title=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/04/08/world/holocaust-lamentations-echo-at-vatican.html|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/04/03/world/pope-offers-conciliation-to-jews-and-christians.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|accessdate=2012-08-21|date=1994-04-08}}</ref> and the Concert for the Pope's 80th Birthday in 2000 with the [[Philharmonia Orchestra]], among others,<ref name=NYTimes>{{cite news|last=Stanley|first=Alessandra|title=Musical Friend Grants the Pope's Birthday Wish|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/05/18/arts/arts-abroad-musical-friend-grants-the-pope-s-birthday-wish.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|accessdate=2012-08-21|newspaper=The New York Times|date=2000-05-18}}</ref> had earned him the sobriquet "The Pope's Maestro." In realizing the concert, Levine sought to fulfill the Pontiff's wish to reach out to the followers of the [[Abrahamic faiths]] ([[Judaism]], [[Christianity]], and [[Islam]]), as part of the celebrations dedicated to the 25th anniversary of his pontificate.<ref name=Post-Gazette>{{cite news|last=Roddy|first=Dennis B.|title=Pope in peace concert|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/news/world/pope-in-peace-concert-525669/?print=1|accessdate=2012-08-18|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=2004-01-18}}</ref>
The concert was webcast and broadcast on [[PBS]] and internationally, as well as released on DVD.<ref name=WQED>{{cite web|last=WQED|title=Papal Concert|url=http://www.wqed.org/press/papal_concert.shtml|accessdate=2012-08-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090308093721/http://www.wqed.org/press/papal_concert.shtml|archivedate=2009-03-08|df=}}</ref> It brought together performers from across the globe, including the [[Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra]], which became the first American orchestra to perform at the Vatican for a Pope,<ref name="PSO Music for the Spirit">{{cite web|last=Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra|title=Music for the Spirit|url=http://culturaldistrict.org/production/33587/music-for-the-spirit-2012#tab=overview|accessdate=2012-08-19}}</ref> the [[London Philharmonic Choir]], the [[Krakow Philharmonic]] Choir, the Ankara State Polyphonic Choir, and members of the Mendelssohn Choir of Pittsburgh, as well as vocal soloists [[Ruth Ziesak]] and Birgit Remmert, both from Germany.
The Pittsburgh Symphony, which Levine selected for the occasion,<ref name="Pittsburgh Catholic">{{cite news|last=Bartos|first=Patricia|title=Reconciliation through Music|url=http://www.pittsburghcatholic.org/newsarticles_more.php?id=2953|accessdate=2012-08-20|newspaper=Pittsburgh Catholic|date=2010-12-29}}</ref> has described the Papal Concert of Reconciliation as an “unprecedented opportunity which remains one of the most significant events in the PSO’s history."<ref name="PSO Music for the Spirit" /> The concert also marked that orchestra’s first known appearance on PBS after an absence of more than 20 years, dating back to the “Previn and the Pittsburgh” PBS series, which ran from 1977-1980.<ref name="PSO History">{{cite web|last=Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra|title=PSO History|url=http://pso.culturaldistrict.org/pso_home/web/orchestra-history|accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
In an effort to sustain the extraordinary level of enthusiasm shown by Pittsburgh natives for the Vatican performance, the Pittsburgh Symphony, at Levine's initiative, subsequently developed a concert series called "Music for the Spirit."<ref name=Tribune-Review>{{cite news|last=Kanny|first=Mark|title=Concert series aims to memorialize 'Music for the Spirit'|url=http://triblive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/ae/music/s_411162.html|accessdate=2012-08-20|newspaper=Pittsburgh Tribune-Review|date=2006-01-07}}</ref> Levine conducted the first three of these, which included a performance of the [[Verdi]] [[Requiem (Verdi)|Requiem]] in [[Heinz Hall]], the [[Haydn]] "[[The Creation (Haydn)|Creation]]" to celebrate the centenary of [[Cathedral of Saint Paul (Pittsburgh)|St. Paul's Cathedral]],<ref name="PSO Blog">{{cite web|last=Greer|first=Peter|title=St. Paul Cathedral Centenary Concert|url=http://Cathedral_of_Saint_Paul_(Pittsburgh)|accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref> and a performance of [[Gustav Mahler]]'s [[Symphony No. 3 (Mahler)|Symphony No. 3]], also in Heinz Hall.<ref name="Tribune-Review Mahler 3">{{cite news|last=Kanny|first=Mark|title=Gilbert, PSO showcase Mahler symphony|url=http://triblive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/ae/more/s_458965.html|accessdate=2012-08-20|newspaper=Pittsburgh Tribune-Review|date=2006-06-22}}</ref> The Pittsburgh Symphony has continued the series in subsequent years.<ref name="PSO Music for the Spirit" />
==Program==
The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, with the support of the [[Knights of Columbus]], commissioned American composer [[John Harbison]], winner of the [[Pulitzer Prize for Music]], to write a sacred motet “Abraham," for double chorus and brass, which received its world premiere at this concert.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SGH4pf2EHSs Abraham]</ref> The major work on the program was Mahler's [[Symphony No. 2 (Mahler)|Symphony No. 2]], “Resurrection."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6C1htRMKtlQ Resurrection]</ref>
Harbison dedicated the work "to His Holiness Pope John Paul II in honor of his pontificate-long dedication to fostering reconciliation of the people of Abraham -- Jews, Christians, and Muslims -- and with deep gratitude to Maestro Sir Gilbert Levine, KCSG, for his 15-year-long creative collaboration with His Holiness, which led to the great honor of this commission."<ref name="MIT Tech">{{cite news|last=Baskin|first=Jeremy|title=John Harbison: The Pope's Composer|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V123/N62/harbison_.62a.html|accessdate=2012-08-19|newspaper=The Tech|date=2003-12-09}}</ref> The text of the piece, taken from [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 17 reads: "And when Abraham was ninety years old and nine, the Lord appeared to Abraham and said unto him, 'I am the Almighty God; walk before me, and be thou perfect...and thou shalt be a father of many nations.'"
As the [[Pittsburgh Catholic]] reported, "Levine selected the Mahler piece because it focuses on the soul’s path to resurrection. The pope agreed, because of its theme of 'where the soul is reaching to everlasting life, an idea common to all three religions.'<ref name="Pittsburgh Catholic" /> Levine and the Vatican also considered the symphony particularly appropriate because of the first movement's "special meaning for the pope," stemming from its likely connection to the Polish poet [[Adam Mickiewicz]]'s epic 'Funeral Rites,' which "resonated with John Paul not only generally as the first Polish pope, but also personally, because as a young, aspiring actor, the future pope acted in a Mickiewicz play and memorized his poetry."<ref name="Post-Gazette Mahler">{{cite news|last=Druckenbrod|first=Andrew|title=PSO and guest conductor relish challenges presented by Vatican concert|url=http://old.post-gazette.com/ae/20040113vatican0113fnp1.asp|accessdate=2012-08-20|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=2004-01-13}}</ref> Following the finale of the symphony, the Pope requested an encore—an unprecedented act for a papal concert.<ref name=Post-Gazette /> Because Vatican protocol then restricted all concerts to a duration of 72 minutes, only movements 1, 4, and 5 of the Mahler were performed.<ref name=Post-Gazette />
==See also== *[[Pope John Paul II's relations with Judaism]] *[[Pope_John_Paul_II#Islam|Pope John Paul II's relations with Islam]] *[[Christian–Jewish reconciliation]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SGH4pf2EHSs Video of "Abraham" from concert] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6C1htRMKtlQ Video of Mahler Mvt. 1 from concert] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9vC3zMUjpOc Video of Mahler Mvt. 4 from concert] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gt2qrPNVQWk Video of Mahler Mvt. 5 from concert] *[https://www.amazon.com/Popes-Maestro-Sir-Gilbert-Levine/dp/0470490659/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1345565223&sr=1-1&keywords=the+pope%27s+maestro Levine's Book, "The Pope's Maestro," which includes a detailed account of the concert]

'''Paul Procopolis''' is the name given to a non-existent [[classical music|classical]] [[piano|pianist]] who was credited as a performer on various recordings.
With the advent of cheap long-playing records, unscrupulous companies issued records of material under pseudonyms to avoid paying royalties or because they did not own the [[copyright]] to the recordings. In the case of Paul Procopolis, the reasons for the recording company, [[Saga Records]] issuing recordings pseudonymously are uncertain, as they would have had the copyright to at least some of the material. According to Robin O'Connor (see external links), the company's intention was to compile pre-existing recordings by several different performers on one album and present them as the work of a single performer.
The name Paul Procopolis was used to reissue recordings by the pianist [[Sergio Fiorentino]], including the complete [[Chopin]] waltzes, extracts from [[Bach]]'s ''Well-Tempered Clavier'', and works by [[Liszt]]. Some of the LPs included a biography of Procopolis who, it was alleged, was born in Athens in 1934, studied with Nadia Boulanger in Paris and lived and taught in Greece. The biography was written by Robin O'Connor. Various other LPs give no biographical information at all.
Ernst Lumpe has attempted to identify the real artists in the Procopolis recordings. Other pianists whose recordings were issued under this name included [[Bernard Vitebsky]] (his Beethoven concerto number 3), [[Albert Ferber]] (an LP of "The World's Best Loved Piano Music") and [[Clive Lythgoe]]. The recording of the second Chopin concerto has been identified as that of the Brazilian pianist [[Carmen Vitis Adnet]] (who lived in Vienna and was married to pianist [[Hans Graf]]) with the [[Vienna Symphony]] under [[Hans Swarowsky]]. Further recordings (such as the first Chopin concerto) remain unidentified.{{cn|date=April 2017}}
==Sources== * The Fiorentino recordings issued under the name of Procopolis are identified at [http://www.fortepianos.org/elumpe/SFDiscography.html Ernst Lumpe's website]. * Robin O'Connor, the man who assembled many of the Paul Procopolis LPs, recounts how they came into being on the [http://www.musicweb-international.com/classrev/2007/Feb07/saga_remembered.htm MusicWeb website].
{{DEFAULTSORT:Procopolis, Paul}} [[Category:Fictional musicians]] [[Category:House names]] [[Category:Musical hoaxes]]

22 civilians killed (state news agency claim){{cite web|last=Dettmer |first=Jamie |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/10/24/ex-gaddafi-stronghold-surrenders-to-pro-government-forces.html |title=Ex-Gaddafi Stronghold Surrenders to Pro-Government Forces |publisher=The Daily Beast |date= |accessdate=2014-01-02}} }} {{Campaignbox 2011–2012 Libyan factional fighting}} The '''Siege of Bani Walid''' was a military conflict in [[Libya]]. ==History== [[Bani Walid]] is an oasis town in western Libya which has a historic rivalry with the city of [[Misrata]]. During the civil war in 2011, Bani Walid remained a bastion of support for the government of [[Muammar Gaddafi]] until the very end of the war, while Misrata was one of the first towns to rise up, emerging victorious from a [[Battle of Misrata|months-long siege]]. After the end of the war, a number of Misratan militias made efforts to capture those people whom they believed were linked to the previous government. After a string of abuses, local fighters in Bani Walid retook control of their town and expelled the new government from the city. The brigade was then involved in revenge kidnappings with Misrata during the majority of 2012.{{cite news | author = Chris Stephen | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/oct/19/muammar-gaddafi-militias-final-assault | title = One year on from Muammar Gaddafi's death, militias line up for final assault | publisher = The Guardian | date = 2012-10-19 | accessdate = 2012-10-20 | location=London}} In July, while they were holding two Misratan journalists, fighters in Bani Walid captured and tortured Misratan militiaman Omran Shaaban, one of the original [[Death of Muammar Gaddafi|captors of Gaddafi]] at the end of the [[Battle of Sirte (2011)|battle of Sirte]]. He died later of his wounds. In response, the Libyan Congress authorized the use of force against Bani Walid to capture those responsible for the deaths, setting a deadline of 5 October for the town to peacefully comply. The local government of Bani Walid rejected the decision, stating that no true judiciary system existed in Libya. Following this event, the armed forces of the new government and allied independent militias mounted a siege on the city. ==Fighting== At the end of September, the Libyan Shield brigade from the Libyan government and Misrata militias cut the roads leading to Bani Walid, preventing civilian supplies from entering the city. Amnesty International protested against the siege of the city.{{cite web | url = https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/libyan-authorities-must-avoid-unnecessary-and-excessive-use-force-bani-walid-2012-10-05 | title = Libya: Bani Walid siege must be lifted | publisher = [[Amnesty International]] | date = 2012-10-05 | accessdate = 2012-10-20}} On 2 October, clashes erupted between the pro-government militias from Misrata and local militiamen in Bani Walid. One person was killed and 5-10 were wounded.{{cite news | title = Fatal clashes reported outside Bani Walid as forces muster for possible assault | url= http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=15547 | publisher = [[Libya Herald]] | date = 2012-10-02 | accessdate = 2012-10-07}}{{cite news |title = Clashes near Libya's Bani Walid kill one, raise tensions |url = http://www.thesundaily.my/news/505861 |publisher = The Sun Daily |agency = Agence France-Presse |date = 2012-10-03 |accessdate = 2012-10-07 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121007094122/http://www.thesundaily.my/news/505861 |archivedate = 2012-10-07 |df = }} On 10 October, violent clashes erupted between Bani Walid militias and Misrata militias in the valley of Mardum, 10 km east of Bani Walid. One Bani Walid fighter was killed and two others injured, while the overall death toll was put at 10 killed.{{cite web | url = http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2012/Oct-10/190902-deadly-clashes-rock-libyas-bani-walid.ashx | title = Deadly clashes rock Libya's Bani Walid | publisher = [[The Daily Star (Lebanon)]] ([[Agence France-Presse|Agence France-Presse (AFP)]]) | date = 2012-10-10 | accessdate = 2012-10-23}} 5-10 civilians died due to shelling by the Misrata militias while some supplies were successfully delivered to the city.{{cite web | url = http://reliefweb.int/report/libya/deadly-clashes-rock-libyas-bani-walid | title = Deadly clashes rock Libya's Bani Walid | publisher = [[ReliefWeb]] ([[Agence France-Presse|Agence France-Presse (AFP)]]) | date = 2012-10-10 | accessdate = 2012-10-20}} On 17 October, Bani Walid was shelled once again as ground clashes raged. Five government militiamen were killed and 44 wounded in the fighting,{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/oct/19/libyan-army-storms-bani-walild | title = Confusion rife as Libyan army storms town of Bani Walid | publisher = The Guardian | date = 2012-10-19 | accessdate = 2012-10-23 | location=London | first=Chris | last=Stephen}} while seven Bani Walid residents died in the shelling and 75 were wounded.{{cite web | url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g7FkjTes4WIv3H2yIcQw0il5kiMA?docId=CNG.84104af02afdc00c1fb46ca311ffabed.421 | title = 11 killed as Libyan forces clash with Kadhafi diehards | publisher = [[Google News]] (AFP) | date = 2012-10-18 | accessdate = 2012-10-23}} On 18 October, around 2,000 [[Libyan National Army]] units and its aligned militias, mainly from city of [[Misrata]], started, after failed negotiations between the government and the local council, full-scale attack on [[Bani Walid]]. Army spokesman claimed that army moved quickly and secured town airport and was closing to city centre. This was denied by residents of the town who claimed that the airport was still under local militias control and that the army had not entered the town.{{cite web | url = http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=16390 | title = Exclusive: Full-scale assault on Bani Walid begins | publisher = [[Libya Herald]] | date = | accessdate = 2012-10-23}} Meanwhile, the chief of staff, Yussef al-Mangush said that the army will be sent to the city and will take over to impose security. He added that he hoped that the army would be able to enter the city peacefully.{{cite web | url = http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/10/18/244575.html | title = Libyan army to head to Bani Walid after clashes | publisher = [[Al Arabiya|Al Arabiya (English)]] | date = 2011-10-18 | accessdate = 2012-10-20}} On 19 October, the Misrata militias and the Libyan army had pulled back, and the president of the transitional congress imposed a 48-hour ceasefire, condemning the "unauthorized assault" of the Misrata and government forces. Eight government soldiers and militiamen were killed in the fighting, while 12 people from Bani Walid, fighters and residents.{{cite web | url = http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=16430 | title = Magarief condemns Bani Walid assault as 48-hour ceasefire declared | publisher = [[Libya Herald]] | date = | accessdate = 2012-10-20}} A Libyan officer told that the ceasefire was to allow civilians to leave the city, but locals said that they won't leave their city.{{cite news | last = Stephen | first = Christopher | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-10-19/libya-fighting-at-bani-walid-continues-into-fourth-day.html | title = Libya Fighting at Bani Walid Continues Into Fourth Day | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 2011-10-19 | accessdate = 2012-10-20}} Their closest position to Bani Walid was some 25 miles from the town itself, a point captured during the offensive between 16 and 18 October. Despite claims from Margarief that the resolution needed to be peaceful, the Libyan Army and its allied militia was preparing another assault, moving heavy weapons and ammunition to the battlefield. The shelling on the city and its outskirts continued and the ceasefire was ignored, with five residents, including a child, killed and 40 houses destroyed by the rockets fired by the militias. The shelling was concentrated on the Valley of Mardoum. The military commander of Bani Walid stated that his forces were still in full control of the city. Libyan Shields forces and Misrata militias stated that their offensive had been sanctioned by the government, while a military official denied it, adding to the confusion.{{cite web | url = http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/57730-at-least-2-dead-in-shelling-of-ex-gadhafi-bastion-in-libya | title = At Least 2 Dead in Shelling of ex-Gadhafi Bastion in Libya | publisher = [[Naharnet]] | date = 2011-10-19 | accessdate = 2012-10-20}} The talks between Bani Walid and pro Misrata government forces for a negotiated solution collapsed.{{cite web | url = http://www.news-journalonline.com/article/20121019/API/1210190891?p=1&tc=pg | title = Clashes for 3rd straight day in Libyan town | publisher = [[The Daytona Beach News-Journal]] | date = 2012-10-19 | accessdate = 2012-10-20}} On 20 October, Misrata militias launched another assault against Bani Walid, trying to push into the city center. At least nine Misrata soldiers were killed and 122 others were injured.{{cite web | url = http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArticleDetails.aspx?ID=448828 | title = Clashes in ex-Qaddafi bastion kill 9, 122 wounded | publisher = [[NOW Lebanon]] | date = 2012-10-23 | accessdate = 2012-10-23}} The death toll was later updated to 22 Misrata soldiers killed and more than 200 wounded, while Bani Walid casualties numbered to four killed, including a young girl and 23 injured.{{cite news | url = http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4294673,00.html | title = Libya: 26 dead, over 200 injured | publisher = [[Ynetnews]] | date = 2012-10-20 | accessdate = 2012-10-23}}{{cite news | url = http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/292848/26-killed-more-than-200-wounded-in-clashes-in-ex-gadhafi-bastion-medics | title = 26 killed, more than 200 wounded in clashes in ex-Gadhafi bastion – medics | agency = [[Agence France-Presse]] | date = 2012-10-21 | accessdate = 2012-10-23}} Some civilians were leaving Bani Walid because of the random shelling killing civilians and the lack of food and drink. Militiamen said that they had a list of wanted people inside Bani Walid and that there were in addition hundreds more gunmen defending the city.{{cite news | url = http://m.apnews.com/ap/db_15727/contentdetail.htm?contentguid=uMhT0zmy | title = Libyan turmoil persists year after Gadhafi death | agency = [[Associated Press]] | date = 2012-10-20 | accessdate = 2012-10-23}} On 21 October, the shelling from Misrata militias on the city resumed with smoke flying over some parts of the city, Abdelkarim Ghomaid, a Bani Walid commander reported. He added that they had captured 16 armed cars from Misrata militias.{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/21/us-libya-clashes-idUSBRE89K07G20121021 | title = Protesters break into grounds of Libya's parliament | agency = [[Reuters]] | date = 2012-10-21 | accessdate = 2012-10-23}} The fighting on the ground resumed as well for a fifth day after Misrata and government forces regrouped after the bloody losses suffered the previous day.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2012/10/21/libya-22-militiamen-killed-in-assault-on-gadhafi-loyalist-stronghold/ |title=Libya: 22 militiamen killed in assault on Gadhafi loyalist stronghold |publisher=Fox News |date=2012-10-21 |accessdate=2014-01-02}} A resident told that clashes happened on the outskirts of the city, but that they were less intense than the previous day.[https://archive.is/20130115115848/http://www.cbc.ca/m/rich/world/story/2012/10/21/bani-walid-libya.html ] A Misrata militiamen said that the fighters in Bani Walid were well armed and that fighting continued at the Wadi Dinar, gates, 30 miles away from the city centre and that they traded fire from two hilltops. He added that the battle was going to take some time.{{cite web|url=http://hosted2.ap.org/OREUG/86053d8662944f7698388c63189f97c6/Article_2012-10-21-Libya/id-0204d4083e4143d3a618d7f75a9f1d2b |title=Associated Press | The Register-Guard | Eugene, Oregon |publisher=Hosted2.ap.org |date=2009-09-17 |accessdate=2014-01-02}} In Tripoli, around 500 protesters invaded the grounds of the Libyan parliament to protest against the attacks on Bani Walid.{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFL5E8LL25V20121021 |title=UPDATE 3-Protesters break into grounds of Libya's parliament | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date= 2012-10-21|accessdate=2014-01-02}} On 22 October, more clashes near the town left another two pro-government fighters dead.{{cite web|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFL5E8LMDWW20121022?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0|title=Civilians flee besieged former Gaddafi stronghold in Libya|publisher=|accessdate=22 November 2014}} On 23 October Colonel Ali al-Shekhili claimed that the Army has control of the airport, hospital and other important places. The Airport takeover, together with the military occupation of Mordum, Shmeagh and Tniena districts on the outskirts was confirmed by one of the refugees who fled the city. The Colonel said that the Army met little resistance and said that they are shelling the city. A local said that the Army is entering the city with bulldozers demolishing houses.{{cite news|title=Army pushes into Bani Walid as Libya marks anniversary |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/10/23/uk-libya-anniversary-idUKBRE89M14L20121023 |publisher=Reuters |date=23 October 2012 |accessdate=24 October 2012}}[http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=16683 Bani Walid residents say military in control of surrounding districts as tens of thousands flee] On 24 October, pro-government fighters mostly from Libya Shield brigade, militia under command of the Ministry of Defence, took control of centre of the city. Army and militia units still faced resistance in certain parts of the town.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/24/us-libya-clashes-idUSBRE89N0WL20121024|title=Pro-government forces take control of old Gaddafi bastion Bani Walid|work=Reuters|accessdate=22 November 2014}} The defenders had retreated from the city to the valleyrs around.http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/libyan-militia-takes-former-gaddafi-town/story-fnejo58q-1226503114782 On 25 October, Mummar Gaddafi loyalists hold out in last stand at Bani Walid,{{cite news|author=Chris Stephen in Bani Walid |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/oct/25/gaddafii-loyalists-last-stand-bani-walid |title=Mummar Gaddafi loyalists hold out in last stand at Bani Walid | World news |publisher=theguardian.com |date= 2012-10-25|accessdate=2014-01-02 |location=London}} just to be scattered by the next day when pro-government forces freely roamed the city. == Aftermath == On 30 October, Libyan Minister of Defence Osama al-Juwail came into conflict with army chief-of-staff Yousef Mangoush over the control of the army over the oasis town. While Mangoush claimed that military operations have ceased and town is under its control, the defence minister stated that militia outside the army's command, not the army itself, are in control of Bani Walid. This was not the first time when Mangoush and Juwail have disagreed, with minister being strongly in favour of greater ministry, rather than military, control over the army. Refugees were also reportedly not allowed to return to their homes, and journalists were forbidden to enterto the city by soldiers and militiamen manning the checkpoints on the outskirts of the city, despite army promises of right of return.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/10/20121029234922385278.html |title=Libyan army has 'no control' in Bani Walid - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2014-01-02}}[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/10/30/defence-minister-says-army-chief-has-no-control-over-bani-walid/ Defence minister says army chief has “no control” over Bani Walid] On 1 November, an AFP reporter was able to enter the town and reported heavy damage from the fighting. The residential area near the university, several buildings in the Gweida district and several public buildings were destroyed by fire, which was blamed by a local medic on militias from both Bani Walid and Misrata, as well as with common criminals. The correspondent also witnessed three separate incidents of thefts by Misratan militiamen. The town still remained largely empty, with only a few police and army patrols in the centre.[http://www.khaleejtimes.com/kt-article-display-1.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2012/November/middleeast_November9.xml§ion=middleeast Libya town wracked by political score-settling] On 16 December, fresh fighting breaks out in Bani Walid. Members of the security forces clashed with armed men in the central Dahra area of Bani Walid today, leaving three members of the armed force dead and a number of other security personnel injured. AFP - Armed men killed four policemen and two soldiers Sunday in separate attacks in Libya, including one in a former bastion of Moamer Kadhafi's regime that was toppled last year, security officials said. On October 5, 2013 Gunmen killed at least 12 Libyan soldiers in an attack on a checkpoint near the city of Bani Walid, a former stronghold of supporters of Muammar Gadhafi, security officials said on Saturday. The ambush happened on the road between Bani Walid and the town of Tarhouna, where the army had a checkpoint. They came under heavy gunfire. Between 12 and 15 soldiers were killed," said Ali Sheikhi, a spokesman for the army joint chief of staff. {{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2013/Oct-05/233676-gunmen-attack-libyan-military-kill-15-soldiers-libya-news-agency.ashx#ixzz2gqQ66XrF |title=Libyan checkpoint ambush kills at least 12 soldiers | News , Middle East |publisher=The Daily Star |date= |accessdate=2014-01-02}} == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bani Walid}} [[Category:2012 in Libya]] [[Category:Bani Walid]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2012]] [[Category:Aftermath of the Libyan Civil War (2011)]]

'''Solder fatigue''' is the mechanical degradation of [[solder]] due to [[deformation (engineering)|deformation]] under cyclic loading. This can often occur at [[stress (mechanics)|stress]] levels below the [[yield stress]] of solder as a result of repeated temperature fluctuations, mechanical [[vibration]]s, or [[structural load|mechanical loads]]. Techniques to evaluate solder fatigue behavior include [[Finite element method|finite element analysis]] and semi-analytical closed form equations.<ref>Serebreni, M., Blattau, N., Sharon, G., Hillman, C., Mccluskey, P. "Semi-analytical fatigue life model for reliability assessment of solder joints in qfn packages under thermal cycling". SMTA ICSR, 2017. Toronto, ON, https://www.researchgate.net/publication/317569529_SEMI-ANALYTICAL_FATIGUE_LIFE_MODEL_FOR_RELIABILITY_ASSESSMENT_OF_SOLDER_JOINTS_IN_QFN_PACKAGES_UNDER_THERMAL_CYCLING</ref>
==Overview== Solder is a [[metal alloy]] used to form electrical, thermal, and mechanical interconnections between the component and [[printed circuit board]] (PCB) substrate in an electronic assembly. Although other forms of cyclic loading are known to cause solder fatigue, it has been estimated that the largest portion of electronic failures are thermomechanically<ref>G. Sharon, "Temperature Cycling and Electronics", http://www.dfrsolutions.com/hubfs/Resources/services/Temperature-Cycling-and-Fatigue-in-Electronics-White-Paper.pdf?t=1507741523533</ref> driven due to [[temperature]] cycling.<ref>Wunderle, B.; B. Michel, "Progress in Reliability Research in Micro and Nano Region", Microelectronics and Reliability, V46, Issue 9-11, 2006.</ref> Under thermal cycling, stresses are generated in the solder due to [[coefficient of thermal expansion]] (CTE) mismatches. This causes the solder joints to experience non-recoverable deformation via [[creep (deformation)|creep]] and [[Plasticity (physics)|plasticity]] that accumulates and leads to degradation and eventual [[fracture]].
Historically, tin-lead solders were common alloys used in the [[electronics industry]]. Although they are still used in select industries and applications, [[lead-free solder]]s have become significantly more popular due to [[Restriction of Hazardous Substances Directive|RoHS]] regulatory requirements. This new trend increased the need to understand the behavior of lead-free solders.
Much work has been done to characterize the creep-fatigue behavior of various solder alloys and develop predictive life damage models using a [[Physics of Failure]] approach. These models are often used when trying to assess solder joint reliability. The [[Solder Fatigue|fatigue]] life of a solder joint depends on several factors including: the alloy type and resulting [[microstructure]], the joint geometry, the component material properties, the PCB substrate material properties, the loading conditions, and the boundary conditions of the assembly.
==Thermomechanical solder fatigue== During a product’s operational lifetime it undergoes temperature fluctuations from application specific temperature excursions and self-heating due to component [[power dissipation]]. Global and local mismatches of coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) between the component, component leads, PCB substrate, and system level effects<ref>http://www.dfrsolutions.com/hubfs/Resources/System_Level_Effects_on_Solder_Joint_Reliability.pdf</ref> drive stresses in the interconnects (i.e. solder joints). Repeated temperature cycling eventually leads to thermomechanical fatigue.
The deformation characteristics of various solder alloys can be described at the microscale due to the differences in composition and resulting microstructure. Compositional differences lead to variations in [[Phase (matter)|phase]](s), grain size, and [[intermetallics]]. This affects susceptibility to [[deformation mechanism]]s such as [[dislocation]] motion, [[diffusion]] and [[grain boundary sliding]]. During thermal cycling, the solder's microstructure (grains/phases) will tend to coarsen<ref>Crina Rauta, Abhijit Dasgupta, Craig Hillman, "Solder Phase Coarsening, Fundamentals, Preparation, Measurement and Prediction", https://www.dfrsolutions.com/hubfs/Resources/services/Solder-Phase-Coarsening-Fundamentals-Preparation-Measurement-and-Prediction.pdf?t=1514473946162</ref> as energy is dissipated from the joint. This eventually leads to crack initiation and [[crack propagation|propagation]] which can be described as accumulated fatigue damage.<ref>http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.115.7354&rep=rep1&type=pdf</ref>
The resulting bulk behavior of solder is described as [[viscoplastic]] (i.e. rate dependent inelastic deformation) with sensitivity to elevated temperatures. Most solders experience temperature exposures near their melting temperature (high [[homologous temperature]]) throughout their operational lifetime which makes them susceptible to significant creep. Several constitutive models have been developed to capture the creep characteristics of lead and lead-free solders. Creep behavior can be described in three stages: primary, secondary, and tertiary creep. When modeling solder, secondary creep, also called steady state creep (constant strain rate), is often the region of interest for describing solder behavior in electronics. Some models also incorporate primary creep. Two of the most popular models are hyperbolic sine models developed by Garofalo<ref>Garofalo, F., 1965, "Fundamentals of Creep and Creep-Rupture in Metals", Macmillan, New York.</ref> and Anand<ref>Anand, L., 1985, "Constitutive Equations for Hot Working of Metals", J. Plasticity, 1(3), pp. 213–231</ref><ref>Brown, S. B.; Kim, K. H.; Anand, L., 1989, "An Internal Variable Constitutive Model for Hot Working of Metals," Int. J. Plasticity, 5(2), pp. 95–130</ref> to characterize the steady state creep of solder. These model parameters are often incorporated as inputs in [[Finite element method|FEA]] simulations to properly characterize the solder response to loading.
==Fatigue models== Solder damage models take a physics of failure based approach by relating a physical parameter that is a critical measure of the damage mechanism process (i.e. inelastic strain range or dissipated strain energy density) to cycles to failure. The relationship between the physical parameter and cycles to failure typically takes on a power law or modified power law relationship with material dependent model constants. These model constants are fit from experimental testing and simulation for different solder alloys. For complex loading schemes, Miner's linear damage superposition law<ref>M. A. Miner, "Cumulative damage in fatigue", Journal of applied mechanics, vol. 12, pp. 159-164, 1945</ref> is employed to calculate accumulated damage.
=== Coffin-Manson model === The generalized Coffin-Manson<ref>L. F. Coffin, "The Problem of Thermal Stress Fatigue in Austenitic Steels", Special Technical Publication 165, ASTM, 1954, p. 31</ref><ref>L. F. Coffin, "A study of the Effects of Cyclic Thermal Stresses on a Ductile Metal", Trans. ASME, 76, 931–950 (August 1954).</ref><ref>S. S. Manson, "Behavior of materials under conditions of thermal stress", Proceedings of the Heat Transfer Symposium, University of Michigan Engineering Research Institute, Ann Arbor, Mich, pp. 9-75, 1953</ref><ref>Dowling, N. E., "Mechanical Behavior of Materials", 2nd Edition, Upper Saddle River, New Jersey, 1999.</ref> model considers the elastic and plastic strain range by incorporating Basquin’s equation<ref>Basquin, O. H. (1910). "The exponential law of endurance test". Proceedings of the American Society for Testing and Materials. 10: 625–630.</ref> and takes the form:
<math>\frac{\Delta\epsilon}{2}=\frac{\sigma^'_f-\sigma_m}{E} (2N_f)^b+\epsilon^'_f (2N_f)^c</math>
Here ''∆ε'' ⁄ 2 represents the elastic-plastic cyclic strain range, ''E'' represents elastic modulus, ''σ<sub>m</sub>'' represents means stress, and ''N<sub>f</sub>'' represents cycles to failure. The remaining variables, namely ''σ<sub>f</sub>'',''ε'<sub>f</sub>'',''b'',and ''c'' are fatigue coefficients and exponents representing material model constants. The generalized Coffin-Manson model accounts for the effects of high cycle fatigue (HCF) primarily due to elastic deformation and [[low cycle fatigue]] (LCF) primarily due to plastic deformation.
=== Engelmaier model === In the 1980s Engelmaier proposed a model,<ref>Engelmaier, W., "Fatigue Life of Leadless Chip Carrier Solder Joints During Power Cycling", Components, Hybrids, and Manufacturing Technology, IEEE Transactions on, vol.6, no.3, pp. 232-237, September 1983</ref> in conjunction with the work of Wild,<ref>Wild, R. N., "Some Fatigue Properties of Solders and Solder Joints", IBM Tech. Rep. 73Z000421, January 1973.</ref> that accounted for some of the limitations of the Coffin-Manson model such as the effects of the frequency and temperature. His model takes a similar power law form:
<math>N_f(50\%)=\frac{1}{2} (\frac{\Delta\gamma}{2 \epsilon'_f})^{\frac{1}{c}}</math>
<math>c=-0.442-6\cdot 10^{-4}T_s+1.74\cdot 10^{-2} \ln (1+f)</math>
Engelmaier relates the total shear strain (∆γ) to cycles to failure (''N<sub>f</sub>''). ''ε'<sub>f</sub>'' and ''c'' are model constants where ''c'' is a function of mean temperature during thermal cycling (''T<sub>s</sub>'') and thermal cycling frequency (''f'').
<math> \Delta \gamma= C ( \frac{L_D}{h_s}) \Delta \alpha \Delta T </math>
∆γ can be calculated as function of the distance from the neutral point (''L<sub>D</sub>'') solder joint height (''h<sub>s</sub>''), coefficient of thermal expansion (∆''α''), and change in temeprate (Δ''T''). In this case ''C'' is empirical model constant.
This model was initially proposed for leadless devices with tin-lead solder. The model has since been modified by Engelmaier and others to account for other phenomena such as leaded components, thermal cycling dwell times, and lead-free solders. While initially a substantial improvement over other techniques to predict solder fatigue, such as testing and simple acceleration transforms, it is now generally acknowledged that Engelmaier and other models that are based on strain range do not provide a sufficient degree of accuracy.
=== Darveaux model === Darveaux<ref>Darveaux, R., 1997, "Solder Joint Fatigue Life Model", in Design & Reliability of Solder and Solder Interconnections, Proceedings of the ‘TMS, Orlando, Florida, February 1997.</ref><ref>Darveaux, R. (2000) Effect of simulation methodology on solder joint crack growth correlation. Electronic Components and Technology Conference, 2000 IEEE, pp 158–169</ref> proposed a model relating the quantity of volume weighted average inelastic work density, the number of cycles to crack initiation, and the crack propagation rate to the characteristic cycles to failure.
<math>N_0=K_1\Delta W^{K_2}_{avg}</math>
<math>\frac{da}{dN}=K_3\Delta W^{K_4}_{avg}</math>
<math>N_f=N_0+\frac{a}{da/dN}=K_1\Delta W^{K_2}_{avg}+\frac{a}{K_3 \Delta W^{K_4}_{avg}}</math>
In the first equation ''N<sub>0</sub>'' represents the number of cycles to crack initiation, ∆W represents inelastic work density, ''K<sub>1</sub>'' and ''K<sub>2</sub>'' are material model constants. In the second equation, da/dN represents the crack prorogation rate, ∆W represents inelastic work density, ''K<sub>3</sub>'' and ''K<sub>4</sub>'' are material model constants. In this case the crack propagation rate is approximated to be constant. ''N<sub>f</sub>'' represents the characteristic cycles to failure and a represents the characteristic crack length. Model constants can be fit for different solder alloys using a combination of experimental testing and [[Finite Element Analysis]] (FEA) simulation.
The Darveaux model has been found to be relatively accurate by several authors.<ref>Ye, Yuming, et al. "Assessment on reliability of BGA package double-sided assembled". High Density Packaging and Microsystem Integration, 2007. HDP'07. International Symposium on. IEEE, 2007</ref><ref>Meifunas, M., et al. "Measurement and prediction of reliability for double-sided area array assemblies". Electronic Components and Technology Conference, 2003. Proceedings. 53rd. IEEE, 2003</ref> However, due to the expertise, complexity, and simulation resources required, its use has been primarily limited to component manufacturers evaluating component packaging. The model has not received acceptance in regards to modeling solder fatigue across an entire printed circuit assembly and has been found to be inaccurate in predicting system-level effects (triaxiality) on solder fatigue.<ref>http://www.dfrsolutions.com/hubfs/Developing%20Damage%20Models%20for%20Solder%20Joints%20Exposed%20to%20Complex%20Stress%20States.pdf?t=1505335343846, Hillman, C., "Developing Damage Models for Solder Joints Exposed to Complex Stress States: Influence of Potting, Coating, BGA Mirroring, and Housing on Solder Joint Fatigue", Proceedings of the EMPC, Warsaw, Poland, September, 2017</ref>
=== Blattau model === The current solder joint fatigue model preferred by the majority of electronic [[OEM]]s worldwide is the [http://www.dfrsolutions.com/about-us/dfr-solutions-team Blattau] model, which is available in the [[Sherlock Automated Design Analysis|Sherlock Automated Design Analysis software]]. The Blattau model is an effective evolution of the previous models discussed above. Blattau incorporates the use of strain energy proposed by Darveaux, while using closed-form equations based on classic mechanics to calculate the stress and strain being applied to the solder interconnect.<ref>http://www.dfrsolutions.com/hubfs/DfR_Solutions_Website/Resources-Archived/Publications/2005-2007/2006_Blattau_IPC_working.pdf</ref> An example of these stress/strain calculations for a simple leadless chip component is shown in the following equation:
<math>\alpha_1-\alpha_2\cdot \Delta T \cdot L_D=F \cdot ( \frac{L_D}{E_1 A_1}+ \frac{L_D}{E_2 A_2}+\frac{h_S }{A_s G_s}+\frac{h_c}{A_c G_c}+(\frac{2-\nu}{9G_b a})) </math>
Here α is the CTE, T is temperature, ''L<sub>D</sub>'' is the distance to the neutral point, E is elastic modulus, A is the area, h is the thickness, G is shear modulus, ν is [[Poisson's ratio]], and a is the edge length of the copper bond pad. The subscripts 1 refer to the component, 2 and b refer to the board, and s refer to the solder joint. The shear stress (∆τ) is then calculated by dividing this calculated force by the effective solder joint area. Strain energy is computed using the shear strain range and shear stress from the following relationship:
<math> \Delta W= \frac{1}{2}\Delta \gamma \Delta \tau </math>
This approximates the [[hysteresis]] loop to be roughly equilateral in shape. Blattau uses this strain energy value in conjunction with models developed by Syed<ref name=Syed>Syed, A., "Accumulated Creep Strain and Energy Density Based Thermal Fatigue Life Prediction Models for SnAgCu Solder Joints", ECTC 2004, pp. 737-746 - corrected.</ref> to relate dissipated strain energy to cycles to failure.
===Other fatigue models=== Additional strain range and strain energy based models have been proposed by several others.<ref name=Syed/><ref>S. Knecht; L. Fox, "Integrated matrix creep: Application to accelerated testing and lifetime prediction", in Solder Joint Reliability Theory and Applications, J. H. Lau, Ed. New York: Van Nostrand Reinhold, 1991, ch. 16.</ref><ref>Lee, W. W.; Nguyen, L. T.; Selvaduray, G. S., "Solder joint fatigue models: review and applicability to chip scale packages". Microelectronics Reliability 40 (2000) 231-244, 1999.</ref>
==Vibration and cyclic mechanical fatigue==
While not as prevalent as thermomechanical solder fatigue, [[vibration fatigue]] and cyclic mechanical fatigue are also known to cause solder failures. Vibration fatigue is typically considered to be high cycle fatigue (HCF) with damage driven by elastic deformation and sometimes plastic deformation. This can depend on the input excitation for both [[harmonic]] and [[random vibration]]. Steinberg<ref>Steinberg, D. S. "Vibration analysis for electronic equipment". John Wiley & Sons, 2000.</ref> developed a vibration model to predict time to failure based on the calculated board displacement. This model takes into account the input vibration profile such as the [[power spectral density]] or acceleration time history, the natural frequency of the circuit card, and the transmissibility. Blattau developed a modified Steinberg model<ref>http://resources.dfrsolutions.com/Guarantee-Reliability-with-Vibration-Simulation-and-Testing.pdf</ref> that uses board level strains rather than displacement and has sensitivity to individual package types.
Additionally, low temperature isothermal mechanical cycling is typically modeled with a combination of LCF and HCF strain range or strain energy models. The solder alloy, assembly geometry and materials, boundary conditions, and loading conditions will affect whether fatigue damage is dominated by elastic (HCF) or plastic (LCF) damage. At lower temperatures and faster strain rates the creep can approximated to be minimal and any inelastic damage will be dominated by plasticity. Several strain range and strain energy models have been employed in this type of a case, such as the Generalized Coffin-Manson model. In this case, much work has been done to characterize the model constants of various damage models for different alloys.
==See also== * [[Cold solder joint]] * [[Fatigue (material)]] * [[Vibration fatigue]] * [[Creep (deformation)|Creep]] * [[Plasticity (physics)|Plasticity]] * [[Potting (electronics)]]

'''The Bandit Run''' is a reenactment of the journey portrayed in the 1977 film, ''[[Smokey and the Bandit]]''. The reenactment first took place on May 15, 2007 and has become an annual event.
The reenactment was the brainchild of David Hershey and Dave Hall who wanted to commemorate the 30-year anniversary of the classic film. Hall, of the website, ''Restore a Muscle Car'' <ref> [http://www.restoreamusclecar.com Restore a Muscle Car] </ref> and Hershey came up with the idea shortly after Hershey purchased his restored 1977 [[Pontiac Trans Am]] from him in 2006.
==2007== Following the same route that the characters Bo "Bandit" Darville ([[Burt Reynolds]]) and Cledus "Snowman" Snow ([[Jerry Reed]]) made in the 1977 movie, a group of about 30 Trans Ams started out in [[Texarkana]] on May 15, 2007. There, they had a send-off at the Classic Car Museum. Both Texarkana mayors also got involved and gave a send off speech to the group. Heading east on the three-day trip, <ref> [http://www.thebanditrunphotos.com/images/newsalert/banditrunmap07.pdf view 2007 map] </ref> they were joined by ''[[Hot Rod Magazine]]''<ref>[http://www.hotrod.com/eventcoverage/hrdp_0709_bandit_pontiac_trans_am_run/index.html Smokey And The Bandit Pontiac Trans Ams - Bandit Run]</ref> and ''[[Automobile Magazine]]''. After an evening in Tupelo, the growing group of Bandit Runners received another send-off at the Tupelo Auto Museum on May 16. From there, they headed toward [[Birmingham, Alabama]].
There was a stop at the [[Talladega Superspeedway]], where the Bandit Runners were given a tour of the museum, a group photo and lunch. Then, a short drive brought them to their destination, the Year One Facility, for the annual ''Year One Experience'', a three-day event.
The group in Atlanta totaled more than 100 Trans Ams and other cars. Local and national media was there to cover the event, and the Bandit Run was featured on ''Hot Rod TV'' and the [[DIY Network]]. To finish the weekend off, local Bandit Runner Tyler H gave the group a movie location tour around Atlanta, and visited some of the movie's most famous sites.
==References== <references/>
== External links == * [http://www.thebanditrun.com Official ''The Bandit Run'' website] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/27/automobiles/27BANDIT.html On This Run, Way More Bandits Than Smokeys (but No Beer)] at ''[[The New York Times]]'', May 27, 2007 * [http://www.thebanditrunphotos.com The Bandit Run Photos]
